ARTICLE II. - SINGLE STATE CONSTRUCTION CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Single state construction code, MCL 125.1501 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-31. - Enforcement. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the Stille-DeRossett-Hale single state construction code act (MCL 125.1501 et seq.), the building department/permits and code enforcement department of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under such act. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of the act and of the single state construction code throughout its corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. 1998-3, § 1, 6-1-1998) 
Sec. 6-32. - Fees. 
    All fees under the single state construction code board of appeals shall be as established by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
Sec. 6-33. - Registration of state contractor licenses. 
    Any person who holds a state contractor's license of any kind and who desires to do business in the city shall register such license with the city and pay a registration fee to the city as established by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
Secs. 6-34-6-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AMSA BOARD OF APPEALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-101 et seq. 

Sec. 6-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    AMSA means the area metropolitan services agency authorized under the urban cooperation act, 1967 PA 7 (MCL 124.501 et seq.). 
    AMSA area means the Townships of Leroy, Newton, Pennfield, the Charter Townships of Bedford and Emmett, and the Cities of Battle Creek and Springfield. 
    Citizen of the jurisdiction means a citizen of the AMSA area. 
    Inspection official means the person, department or division designated by the city to perform construction code inspections within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1988-5, § 3; Code 1972, § 81/2-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-52. - Established; membership. 
(a)	There is hereby established the AMSA board of appeals for the participating municipalities of the area metropolitan service agency to act as the construction code board of appeals. The AMSA board of appeals shall consist of six members. 
(b)	The members shall be proposed by the AMSA council and confirmed by the city council. One member shall be appointed for six years, one for five years, one for four years, one for three years, one for two years and one for one year; thereafter, each new member shall serve for six years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(c)	During the absence of a member of the AMSA board of appeals by reason of disability or disqualification, the appointing officer shall designate a qualified substitute. The AMSA board of appeals shall select one of its members to serve as chair, and shall designate a clerk from the department of building inspection to serve as secretary to the board, who shall keep a detailed record of all proceedings on file in the department. A member of the AMSA board of appeals shall not pass on any question in which that member is engaged as a contractor or material dealer, or in the preparation of plans or specifications, or in which that member has a personal interest. Appointed members of the AMSA board of appeals shall serve on a voluntary basis and shall receive no compensation for such service. 
(Ord. No. 1988-5, § 4; Code 1972, § 81/2-5) 
Sec. 6-53. - Duties generally. 
    The AMSA board of appeals shall: 
(1)	Administer and enforce the Urban Cooperation Act of 1967, as amended; 
(2)	Administer and enforce the most current edition of the single state construction code; and 
(3)	Hear appeals from the decisions of the inspection official. 
(Ord. No. 1988-5, § 5; Code 1972, § 81/2-6) 
Sec. 6-54. - Appeals. 
(a)	The owner of a building or structure or any other person may appeal to the AMSA board of appeals a decision of the inspection official refusing to grant a modification of the provisions of the single state construction code covering the matter of construction or materials to be used in the erection, alteration or repair. Application for appeal may be made when it is claimed that the true intent of the code or the rules legally adopted under this article have been incorrectly interpreted, that the provisions of the code do not fully apply, or that an equally good or better form of construction can be used. 
(b)	When five qualified members are not present to consider a specific appeal, either the appellant, the inspection official or their representative may request a postponement of the hearing. The AMSA board of appeals shall affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the inspection official by a concurring vote of three members. Every action of the AMSA board of appeals shall be by resolution, and certified copies shall be furnished to the appellant and to the inspection official; except that the appellant shall be entitled to a further hearing before a full board if there were not five qualified members present when the vote was taken. 
(Ord. No. 1988-5, § 6; Code 1972, § 81/2-7) 
Sec. 6-55. - Court review. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of the AMSA board of appeals, whether or not a previous party to the decision, or any officer of the official board of the jurisdiction, may apply to the appropriate court to the jurisdiction for relief. Application for review shall be made to the proper court of the jurisdiction within 15 days after the filing of the board's decision in the office of the inspection official. 
(Ord. No. 1988-5, § 7; Code 1972, § 81/2-8) 
Secs. 6-56-6-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT PROVISIONS 

Sec. 6-61. - Agency designated. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the State Construction Code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, the building official of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of said act throughout the corporate limits of the community adopting this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1, 4-4-2011) 
Sec. 6-62. - Code appendix enforced. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the State Construction Code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, Appendix G of the Michigan Building Code shall be enforced by the enforcing agency within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1, 4-4-2011) 
Sec. 6-63. - Designation of regulated flood prone hazard areas. 
    The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Flood Insurance Study (FIS) Entitled Calhoun County, Michigan (All Jurisdictions) and dated 4/4/11 and the Flood Insurance Rate Map(s) (FIRMS) panel number(s) of 26025C; 0159C, 0178C, 0179C, 0186C, and 0187C and dated 4/4/11 are adopted by reference for the purposes of administration of the Michigan Construction Code, and declared to be a part of Section 1612.3 of the Michigan Building Code, and to provide the content of the "Flood Hazards" section of Table R301.2(1) of the Michigan Residential Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-1, 4-4-2011) 
Secs. 6-64-6-80. - Reserved.

    The state housing law, being 1917 PA 167 (MCL 125.538-125.542) (125.401 et seq.), as last amended, is hereby adopted and readopted as the housing code of the city.     The building inspector shall annually submit to the code official a report of all changes in the housing code adopted by this article and in documents related to such code and shall submit written suggestions regarding such changes and a recommendation as to whether this article should be amended to conform with such changes. 
(Ord. No. 1954-3; Code 1972, § 3-26)

    A certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code of the city, in the State of Michigan, for regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use, and the demolition of such existing structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said property maintenance code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this Code of Ordinances, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 6-102 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1980-7, § 3; Ord. No. 1982-3, § 2; Ord. No. 1986-4, § 2; Ord. No. 1988-2, § 2; Ord. No. 1995-6, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1998-3, § 3(B), 6-1-1998; Code 1972, § 3-28; Ord. No. 2004-2, § 1, 7-19-2004)

ARTICLE V. - DEMOLITION AND MOVING OF BUILDINGS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 40. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-131. - Wrecking operations and procedures. 
(a)	The wrecking of buildings or structures shall be done in a safe, workmanlike manner. Willful or continued performance of work in an unsafe, shoddy, dangerous or unworkmanlike manner shall be cause for the cancellation of the wrecking permit. 
(b)	Barricades subject to the approval, and meeting the requirements, of the building inspection department shall be erected as required to protect the public. Where encroachments are made upon public property or ways, permission therefor shall be obtained in advance from the appropriate department. Trucks and machinery shall be operated in such a manner as not to create a traffic hazard and in accordance with any instructions or directions of the public safety department. Materials shall be disposed of and removed systematically, as the building or structure is wrecked, to prevent the creation of a fire hazard, danger to the public or interference with the use of public property. Proper protection shall be provided in all public utilities, during the operation, to prevent damage or interruption of service. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-110) 
Sec. 6-132. - General regulations. 
(a)	Permits for wrecking or moving shall not be assigned. 
(b)	All work shall be performed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and as described in the application for the permit. 
(c)	No person shall burn any materials on the premises without first obtaining permission from the public safety department. If permission is obtained, burning shall be done in strict accordance with the public safety department's stipulations. 
(d)	No permit shall be issued for the moving or wrecking of buildings or structures if the mover or wrecker has uncompleted work on which the authorized completion date has been exceeded. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-112) 
Sec. 6-133. - Failure of performance; remedy of city. 
    Every permit shall provide, and each permittee shall agree, that on a failure of performance, pursuant to the terms of the application and permit issued under this article, the city may forthwith and without notice complete the moving or wrecking and the costs thereof may be charged, paid and collected as in the manner provided for special assessments. This section shall not preclude suit, for the amount of costs, by the city against the owner or person responsible for the wrecking or moving, in the district court or the circuit court of the county or such other court as may have jurisdiction over actions of this nature. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-113) 
Sec. 6-134. - Variances. 
    The board of building and zoning appeals may grant variances to the provisions of this article in cases where there are unusual, practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships; provided that such a variation will not affect the general health, safety or welfare of the public. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-114) 
Sec. 6-135. - Penalties and sanctions; municipal civil infraction. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article is subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction as provided by section 1-56. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Ord. No. 1997-5, § 3, 12-1-1997; Code 1972, § 3-115) 
Secs. 6-136-6-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 

Sec. 6-151. - Wrecking permits-Required; conditions for issuance; exceptions. 
(a)	Wrecking permits may be issued to wreckers or property owners as follows: 
(1)	To a wrecker, except as prohibited by subsection 6-132(d); and 
(2)	To a property owner intending to wreck a residential building or structure upon the property owner's own premises; provided that the building or structure is not more than a one-story masonry not exceeding 2,000 square feet in size, or a two-story frame, with or without masonry veneer, not exceeding 1,000 square feet of first floor area; and provided, further, that the property owner shall be responsible for compliance with this article. 
(b)	Wrecking permits shall not be required for minor work which is incidental to, and/or in connection with, the repair or alteration of a building or structure for which a building permit has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-104) 
Sec. 6-152. - Same-Application. 
(a)	No person shall commence wrecking a building or structure in the city, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the building inspection department. 
(b)	The application for a wrecking permit shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The street number, property description and number and classification of all structures; 
(2)	The names of all owners of the premises; 
(3)	Written consent to the wrecking by all owners; 
(4)	A complete description of all work to be done and precautions to be taken, including filling, leveling and barricading; 
(5)	Specific starting and completion dates of the operation; 
(6)	A provision for severing existing water, sewer and gas services; and 
(7)	Such other information as the building inspection department deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-105) 
Sec. 6-153. - Moving permits. 
(a)	Required. No person shall commence moving a building or structure without first obtaining a permit therefor from the building inspection department. 
(b)	Approval conditions. The application for the moving of a building or structure shall be approved by the building inspection, the public works, the public safety department of the city, by the city treasurer, and by the private utilities affected by the move. If the moving, in all its phases, conforms with this Code and is approved by all interested officials, the permit shall be granted. These departments and the city treasurer may stipulate conditions for the moving and may also require deposits to be made with the city treasurer to cover the cost of services rendered by the city during the moving operation. Such deposits shall not be construed as the maximum charge for such services. 
(c)	Building permit. No moving permit shall be issued until a building permit has been issued for the new location, if such location is within the city limits. The building permit shall include a plot plan and all alterations and improvements contemplated. 
(d)	Application. Application for a moving permit shall be filed with the building inspection department at least one week before the moving and shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The street number of the building or structure to be moved; 
(2)	The property description of the unit to be moved; 
(3)	The names of all owners of the premises; 
(4)	Written consent to the moving by all owners; 
(5)	A detailed description of the route to be used; 
(6)	The width, length and height of the building or structure, when loaded; height measurements being from the ground to the highest portion of the building or structure after being loaded; 
(7)	The property description and street number to which the building or structure is to be moved, when located within the city limits; 
(8)	The names of all owners of the property to which the building or structure is to be moved, when the property is within the city limits; 
(9)	A plot plan showing the location of the building on its new site, when located within the city limits; and 
(10)	Such other information as the building inspection department official may deem necessary. 
(e)	Fee exemption. No fee shall be charged for moving a building or structure which is not moved on public property. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-106) 
Sec. 6-154. - Restrictions upon permits. 
(a)	Moving. The following restrictions shall be placed upon moving permits: 
(1)	All moving of buildings or structures shall be fully completed within 30 days from the date of issuance of a permit therefor; 
(2)	The premises from which the building or structure is moved shall be cleared of all debris, filled and leveled within seven days, in accordance with accepted standards, except where the excavation is needed or desired for new construction on the premises and a building permit therefor has been issued; 
(3)	An adequate fence or barricade shall be erected completely around open basements or cellars on the same day that the building or structure is moved off the foundation walls and shall be maintained until the filling and leveling off has been completed or new construction has been started; 
(4)	If, in the moving of a building or structure, it becomes necessary to leave the building or structure sitting on the streets or other public thoroughfares after sundown, the contractor shall be responsible for the adequate lighting of the building or structure and all equipment used in connection with the moving process, from sundown to sunrise. 
(b)	Wrecking. The following restrictions shall be placed upon wrecking permits: 
(1)	All work covered by the wrecking permit shall be fully completed within 45 calendar days from the date of issue, unless excepted in the following manner: 
a.	Upon the receipt of a written request, not later than five days prior to the expiration date noted on the approved application, the code official may grant a maximum of 15 days extension of time to complete the wrecking and cleanup of the site if, in the code official's opinion, the size and type of structure, or extremely inclement weather conditions warrant additional time; 
b.	A request for further extension of time shall be acted upon by the building code board of appeals, upon submission of a written request seven days prior to the expiration of the time extension granted by the code official; 
c.	A fee equal to the original fee shall be assessed to the person securing the original permit when wrecking exceeds 60 days, unless such fee is waived by the building code board of appeals. 
(2)	Material may be sold from the premises only during the wrecking period. No materials shall be brought in for sale. Material shall not be sold or stored on the curb, lawn or other public property or property generally used by the public; 
(3)	Removal and disposal of debris; filling and leveling premises: 
a.	The premises on which a building or structure is wrecked shall be cleared of all debris and filled and leveled within ten days after the wrecking operation is completed, except where the excavation is needed or desired for new construction on the premises and a building permit therefor has been applied for or issued. The final six inches of fill shall consist of clean soil, sand or gravel, free of large stones, block, brick, concrete or other such unacceptable materials and shall be left in a neatly graded condition. The ten-day period specified in this subsection (b)(3)a of this section may be extended by the building official, if inclement weather has prohibited the filling and leveling of the premises; 
b.	There shall be no lath, wood or other organic matter used for fill in connection with the wrecking or moving of any building or structure; 
c.	It shall be the obligation of the building wrecker or mover to provide or obtain suitable locations for the disposal of debris resulting from the wrecking or moving operation. The location shall be a state-approved and state-licensed landfill; 
d.	An adequate fence or barricade shall be erected completely around open basements or cellars prior to the removal of the first floor construction and shall be maintained until the filling and leveling off has been completed or new construction has been started. 
(4)	All basement floor slabs which are not to be removed for new construction, when a building is wrecked or moved, shall be thoroughly broken up to permit drainage; 
(5)	All basement walls or foundations which are not to be removed for new construction, when a building is wrecked or moved, shall be broken up and removed to a point one foot below the existing ground surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, §§ 3-107, 3-111) 
Sec. 6-155. - Permit fees. 
    A fee for the moving or wrecking of buildings or structures shall accompany each application and shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-108) 
Sec. 6-156. - Double fees. 
    Whenever a permit is required under this article and such permit is not obtained by the person required to obtain the permit, prior to the commencement of any work, installation or other activity for which the permit is required, the building inspection department shall charge double the normal fee established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1983-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 3-109) 
Secs. 6-157-6-180. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 50. 

Sec. 6-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used by this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private swimming pool means a swimming pool that is not open to the public, is not publicly owned or is not regulated by the state either by statute or by rules or regulations of one of its administrative bodies. 
    Swimming pool means any artificially constructed, nonportable pool capable of being used for swimming or bathing and having a depth of two feet or more at any point. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-212. - Permit required for construction of private swimming pool. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to begin construction on any swimming pool without first obtaining a permit therefor from the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-17) 
Sec. 6-213. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for a permit required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Ord. No. 1981-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 15-18) 
Sec. 6-214. - Plans and specifications to accompany application for permit. 
    Application for a permit required by this article shall be accompanied by a complete and detailed set of plans and specifications of the private swimming pool to be constructed under the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-19) 
Sec. 6-215. - Approval of plans and specifications. 
    Before any permit required by this article shall be issued, the plans and specifications shall be approved by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-20) 
Sec. 6-216. - Final inspection and approval required prior to use. 
    Before any private swimming pool shall be used, a final inspection shall be made and approval given by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-21) 
Sec. 6-217. - Right of entry of county health department and building inspector. 
    The county health department and the building inspector shall have the right at any reasonable hour to inspect any private swimming pool for the purposes of determining that all provisions of this article are fulfilled and complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-22) 
Sec. 6-218. - Drainage requirements when connected to sewer system. 
    The drain line for a private swimming pool may be connected to the city sewer system if the following provisions are complied with: 
(1)	The pool drain shall be connected to the storm sewer if one is available. 
(2)	Where a storm sewer is not available, the pool drain may be connected to a sanitary sewer subject to the approval of the building inspector. 
(3)	There shall be no direct connection between the pool drain and the sewer. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-26) 
Sec. 6-219. - Pool to be constructed to prevent deck water from returning directly to pool. 
    The construction of all private swimming pools shall be made in such a manner that all scum, splash and deck water shall not return to the pool except through a filter system. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-27) 
Sec. 6-220. - Scum controller required; location. 
    All private swimming pools shall be kept free of all floating material, sediment and debris either by an automatic surface skimmer, scum gutter or by some other means approved by the county health department. However, no scum controller shall be extended beyond the inside edge of the pool. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-28) 
Sec. 6-221. - Recirculating system requirements. 
    The entire recirculating system of every private swimming pool shall be capable of filtering and recirculating the entire volume content of the pool during a 12-hour period. The rate of application of pool water on the filters shall not be greater than three gallons per minute per square foot of filter area, unless the county health department shall approve other rates of recirculation or rates of application of water on the filters. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-29) 
Sec. 6-222. - Germ and bacteria control. 
    Provision shall be made for each private swimming pool for positive germ or bacteria control by the use of chlorine, bromine or other disinfecting agents as may be approved by the county health department. Such disinfecting agents shall be applied to the pool water at a uniform rate. Provisions shall be made for adjusting the application thereof so as to keep the germ or bacteria protection of the water in the pool equal to a standard of five-tenths parts per million to 1.0 parts per million chlorine residual. Testing devices capable of accurately measuring such residual shall be provided by the owner or operator. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-30) 
Sec. 6-223. - Violations to constitute nuisance. 
    Any improper or incorrect installation, operation, maintenance or use of any private swimming pool shall constitute a nuisance which may be abated by means of an appropriate court action. 
(Ord. No. 1959-3; Code 1972, § 15-32)

ARTICLE II. - LICENSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Contract, licensing, § 36-136 et seq. 

Sec. 8-31. - "Licensee" defined. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, the term "licensee" shall mean any person to whom a license has been issued under any provision of this Code and the employees or agents of such person. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-32. - When license is required. 
    No person shall engage in the operation, conduct or carrying on of any trade, profession, business or privilege for which any license is required by any section of this Code without first obtaining a license from the city, in the manner and from the city officer required by this article or other provisions of this Code pertaining to a particular license. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-2) 
Sec. 8-33. - Conditions to be met prior to issuance of license. 
    No license shall be granted or delivered until the applicant has complied with all the required conditions precedent to issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-3) 
Sec. 8-34. - Statements of fact in applications to be under oath or affirmation. 
    All statements of fact in any application for a license required by this Code shall be made upon oath or affirmation. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-4) 
Sec. 8-35. - City clerk to be licensing authority; applications to be made to clerk; forms. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, the city clerk shall be the licensing authority of the city and applications for licenses from the city shall be made to the city clerk, upon forms provided by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-5) 
Sec. 8-36. - Investigations; fingerprinting; proof of identity. 
    The city clerk may refer any application for a license to the director of public safety, building inspector or county health officer, or to any two or more of them, for an investigation and recommendation on matters pertaining to the public safety, health or welfare which are or may be involved in the exercise of the license applied for and the city clerk may require the giving of fingerprints, and such other information as may be necessary to establish the identity of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-6) 
Sec. 8-37. - License year; term of licenses. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, the license year of the city shall begin on July 1 in each year and terminate on June 30 of the following year. However, any annual license issued between April 31 and June 30 of any year shall expire on June 30 of the calendar year next following its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-7) 
Sec. 8-38. - License by state as prerequisite to city license. 
    No license required by any provision of this Code shall be issued to any person who is required to have a license or permit from the state until such person shall submit evidence that such person has secured or has made application for such state license or permit. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-8) 
Sec. 8-39. - License certificates property of city; altering and defacing. 
    Each license or permit certificate issued by the city shall be the property of the city and no person shall alter or deface the license or permit certificate. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-9) 
Sec. 8-40. - Acceptance of license constitutes permission for city to enter and inspect premises. 
    Acceptance by any person of a license granted by the city under this Code shall constitute permission by the licensee for any officer of the city, within the authority granted such officer by this Code, to enter upon and inspect the licensed premises at all reasonable times. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-10) 
Sec. 8-41. - Applications for renewal to be treated as original applications. 
    Applications for the renewal of any license required by this Code shall be considered to be and shall be treated in the same manner as an original application for the license. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-11) 
Sec. 8-42. - Fee to be paid prior to issuance of license; persons exempt from fee. 
    No license or permit required by this Code shall be issued prior to payment of the required fee. No license or permit fee shall be required from any person who is exempt from such fee by any provision of state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-12) 
Sec. 8-43. - Refunds upon denial of license or permit. 
    If a license or permit is denied to any applicant, the license or permit fee shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-13) 
Sec. 8-44. - Display of expired or duplicated licenses. 
    No person shall display any expired license or any license for which a duplicate has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-14) 
Sec. 8-45. - Nontransferability. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, licenses issued by the city shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-15) 
Sec. 8-46. - Use of license by others. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided, no person shall permit by lease or otherwise any other person to use or employ any license issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-16) 
Sec. 8-47. - Licenses to be carried on person or posted. 
    Except for a reasonable time after loss or destruction, no person to whom a license has been granted under any provision of this Code shall fail to carry such license upon their person when engaged in the operation, conduct or carrying on of the trade, profession, business or privilege for which the license was granted, except that where the trade, profession, business or privilege is operated, conducted or carried on at a fixed place or establishment, or from or in a vehicle, such license shall be exhibited at all times in some conspicuous place in such place, establishment or vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-17) 
Sec. 8-48. - License to be shown on demand of city officials. 
    No person shall fail to produce any license granted by the city when requested to do so by any city public safety officer, county health officer or city inspector or by any person representing the issuing authority. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-18) 
Sec. 8-49. - When duplicate licenses may be obtained; return of original or affidavit. 
(a)	Any person holding a license under any provision of this Code may obtain a duplicate copy of the license in case the original has been lost, destroyed or so worn or soiled as to be partially or wholly illegible. 
(b)	No duplicate copy of a license shall be issued until the licensee shall return the original to the city clerk, or file an affidavit with the city clerk to the effect that such license has been 
destroyed or lost. Any duplicate issued shall be plainly marked on its face "Duplicate." 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-19) 
Sec. 8-50. - Records to be kept. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of all applications for licenses filed with him, indicating thereon whether the license applied for in each case has been granted or withheld, and, if withheld, the reason therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-21) 
Sec. 8-51. - Suspension and revocation procedure generally. 
(a)	Any license required by this Code may be suspended, or the renewal thereof refused, by the issuing officer for misrepresentation of any material fact in the application for the license. Any license may be suspended by the officer who is responsible for the enforcement thereof for good cause. Such officer shall notify the issuing officer of each such suspension and of the reinstatement of such license upon the termination of such suspension. 
(b)	Any license required by this Code may be revoked by the city council for good cause. No license fee shall be refunded upon revocation or suspension of a license for good cause. 
(c)	The term "good cause," as used in this section, shall mean any act, omission or the permitting of a condition to exist with respect to the license in question which is: 
(1)	Contrary to the health, morals, safety or welfare of the public; 
(2)	Unlawful or fraudulent in nature; 
(3)	A violation of the provisions of this Code under which the license was granted; 
(4)	Beyond the scope of the license issued; 
(5)	A fact, circumstance or condition, which, had it existed or been known to the issuing authority at the time the license was granted, would have been sufficient grounds for the refusal thereof. 
(d)	The good moral character of the licensee shall be determined by the standards set out in 1974 PA 381 (MCL 338.41 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-22) 
Sec. 8-52. - Hearing on revocation; notice. 
    No license under this Code shall be revoked except after a hearing before the city council following not less than ten days' written notice to the licensee stating the time and place of such hearing and setting forth the reasons for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-23) 
Sec. 8-53. - Appeal to city council when license is refused. 
    An applicant for any license who has been refused a license or the renewal of a license for any reason by the authorized issuing officer, unless an appeal is provided to another agency by this Code or by state law, may appeal such refusal to the city council by setting forth all the facts in a written petition and filing the appeal with the city clerk within five days after such refusal. The city council shall grant a hearing to the applicant, upon not less than ten days' written notice thereof to the applicant. The decision of the city council on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-24) 
Sec. 8-54. - Reapplication upon refusal to issue license or revocation of license. 
    No person to whom a license has been refused or whose license has been revoked by the city shall make further application for a license for at least six months after such last previous rejection or revocation, unless the applicant can show, to the satisfaction of the city clerk, that the reason for such rejection or revocation no longer exists. 
(Ord. No. 1954-9; Code 1972, § 8-25) 
Sec. 8-55. - Penalties and sanctions; municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction as set out in section 1-56. 
(Ord. No. 1997-5, § 5, 12-1-1997; Code 1972, § 8-26) 
Secs. 8-56-8-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUTOMOBILE DEALERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Motor vehicle dealers, distributors and manufacturers, MCL 445.1561 et seq. 

Sec. 8-81. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of selling new or used automobiles without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1960-5; Code 1972, § 8-36) 
Sec. 8-82. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and a copy of such resolution shall always be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1960-5; Ord. No. 1981-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 8-37) 
Sec. 8-83. - Adoption of state laws by reference. 
    All statutes of the state relating to new and used automobile dealers are hereby expressly incorporated into and made a part of this Code by reference and no person shall violate any rule, law or regulation contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 1960-5; Code 1972, § 8-38) 
Sec. 8-84. - Automobiles to be in safe condition prior to sale. 
    No person shall sell or expose for sale any automobile under the provisions of this article unless such automobile is safe to operate, conforms in every way to the uniform traffic code adopted by the city and its brakes, lights, horn, tires and other component parts are in good and safe working order. 
(Ord. No. 1960-5; Code 1972, § 8-39) 
Sec. 8-85. - Allowing unlicensed drivers to test drive vehicles prohibited. 
    No person who is the owner or operator of a new or used car business shall permit any person to drive from the licensed premises any motor vehicle for the purpose of test driving the motor vehicle unless the person shall exhibit to the owner or operator of the business a valid driver's license. 
(Ord. No. 1960-5; Code 1972, § 8-41) 
Secs. 8-86-8-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEASONAL BUSINESSES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Transient merchants generally, MCL 445.371 et seq. 

Sec. 8-111. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, a "seasonal business" is defined as any person, whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident of this city or not, who engages in the business of leasing or letting for rent or hire any personal property, or selling or delivering goods, wares or merchandise within the city for a period of less than eight months of any calendar year, and who, in furtherance of such business, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, vehicle, tent, boat, public room in a hotel, lodginghouse or apartment, or any street, alley or other place within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 2; Code 1972, § 8-71) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-112. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in a seasonal business within the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 1; Code 1972, § 8-72) 
Sec. 8-113. - License fee. 
    The fee for a license required by this article for any portion of a year shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and a copy of such resolution shall always be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 3; Ord. No. 1981-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 8-73) 
Sec. 8-114. - Expiration of license. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall expire when the business ceases operation, but not later than June 1 of the year following issuance of the license. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 1; Code 1972, § 8-74) 
Sec. 8-115. - Application; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this article shall be signed by the applicant if an individual, by a partner if a partnership, and by the president or executive officer if a corporation, showing the following: 
(1)	The full name, permanent residence and local address of the applicant; 
(2)	The name of the firm or corporation represented, if any, together with the address of the central or district office of such firm or corporation; 
(3)	The address or location of the places within the city at which the applicant proposes to engage in business; 
(4)	If a corporation, the state of incorporation; 
(5)	The length of time for which the license is desired; 
(6)	Whether the business has previously been licensed under this article and if so, the date of the last license, and whether this application is a renewal; 
(7)	The general description of the type of business to be operated; 
(8)	Such other information as to the identity or character of the persons managing the business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article and the protection of the public good; 
(9)	If the business of the applicant requires the use of weighing or measuring devices, the application shall be accompanied by a certificate from the city clerk stating that the devices have been examined and approved; 
(10)	An affidavit of the applicant to the truth of the statements in the application. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 4; Code 1972, § 8-75) 
Sec. 8-116. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon receipt of the application for a license required by this article and payment of the required fee, the city clerk shall issue a license to operate as a seasonal business. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 5; Code 1972, § 8-76) 
Sec. 8-117. - Contents of license. 
    Each license issued pursuant to this article shall contain the following: 
(1)	The date of issuance; 
(2)	The nature of the business to be conducted under the license; 
(3)	The amount of fee paid; 
(4)	The expiration date; 
(5)	The place where the business may be conducted; 
(6)	The name of the person authorized to conduct the business. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 5; Code 1972, § 8-77) 
Sec. 8-118. - Posting license. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named on the license, where it shall remain in plain sight during the entire time in which the business is conducted. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 6; Code 1972, § 8-78) 
Sec. 8-119. - Separate licenses required for multiple locations. 
    A separate license shall be required for any seasonal business which expects to operate in more than one location, as if each location were a completely separate and distinct business. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 7; Code 1972, § 8-79) 
Sec. 8-120. - Transfer of license. 
    No license shall be transferred without the written consent of the city clerk as evidenced by an endorsement on the face of the license by the city clerk showing to whom the license is transferred and the date of the transfer. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 8; Code 1972, § 8-80) 
Sec. 8-121. - Deceptive representations as to origin of goods; affidavit as to origin. 
    No person licensed under this article shall advertise or hold out that any sale is an insurance, assignee's, executor's, administrator's, mortgagee's, receiver's or closing-out sale, or a sale of mortgaged goods, or of goods, wares and merchandise damaged by fire, smoke, water or otherwise, or that the samples which such licensee is advertising or exposing for sale are samples of any goods described heretofore, either as to their condition or the method of conducting the sale, unless such person shall, at the time of applying for such license, make and file with the city clerk an affidavit showing all the facts in regard to the sale which such person proposes to conduct, including a true statement of the names of the persons from whom the goods to be sold were obtained, the date of delivery of the goods to the licensee, the place from which the goods were brought, and all the details necessary to fully identify the goods. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 10; Code 1972, § 8-82) 
State Law reference- Fire sales, MCL 442.211 et seq. 
Sec. 8-122. - Duty of public safety officers to examine business; enforce article. 
    It shall be the duty of the public safety officers of the city to examine all places of business and persons subject to the provisions of this article to determine if the provisions of this article have been complied with and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1964-2, § 11; Code 1972, § 8-83) 
Secs. 8-123-8-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PRECIOUS METAL AND GEM DEALERS 

Sec. 8-151. - Definitions. 
    The definitions as used in 1981 PA 95 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by reference for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1985-1, § 2; Code 1972, § 8-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-152. - Certificate of registration required; issuance; fee; required information. 
(a)	No person shall engage in the business of a precious metal and gem dealer without first obtaining a certificate of registration therefor as required by 1981 PA 95 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), and paying the fee for such certificate as prescribed by resolution of the city council. Upon payment of the fee, in accordance with the provisions of 1981 PA 95 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), the certificate shall be issued by the public safety department. 
(b)	Any dealer required to be registered under 1981 PA 95 (MCL 445.481 et seq.), shall provide the public safety department with the following information: 
(1)	The name, address and thumbprint of the applicant; 
(2)	The name and address under which the applicant does business; 
(3)	The name, address and thumbprint of all agents or employees of the dealer. Within 24 hours after hiring a new employee, the dealer shall forward to the public safety department the name, address and thumbprint of the new employee. 
(c)	The applicant shall inform the public safety department of any changes in the information required by this section within 24 hours of the change, except that any change in the dealer's name or address under which the dealer does business shall be provided to the public safety department ten days before the change. No person shall falsify information provided to the public safety department pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 1985-1, § 2; Code 1972, § 8-202) 
Secs. 8-153-8-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADULT BUSINESSES 

Sec. 8-181. - Purposes. 
    In the development and execution of this article, it is recognized that there are some uses which, because of their very nature, have serious operational characteristics, particularly when one or more of them are located in near proximity to residential zones, thereby having a deleterious effect upon adjacent areas. Regulation of these uses through location is necessary to ensure that the adverse effects of such uses will not contribute to the blighting or downgrading of the surrounding neighborhood. The provisions of this article are intended to prevent deterioration or blighting of residential neighborhoods. 
(Ord. No. 1992-5, § 1, 5-18-1992; Code 1972, app. A-4, § A-4.1) 
Sec. 8-182. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult bookstore means an establishment which has a substantial portion of its stock-in-trade for sale or rent, which stock-in-trade consists of books, magazines, newspapers, videotapes, video discs and motion pictures which are characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or which establishment excludes admission to minors by virtue of age. 
    Adult business means, but it not limited to, adult bookstores, adult video stores, adult personal service businesses, adult cabarets, adult novelty businesses, massage parlors, nude modeling studios and tattoo parlors. 
    Adult cabaret means a cafe, restaurant or bar where patrons are entertained by dancers, strippers or male or female impersonators, whether accompanied by music or not, whose conduct is characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Adult novelty business means a business which has as a principle activity the sale of devices which stimulate human genitals or devices designed for sexual stimulation. 
    Adult personal service business means a business having as its principle activity a person, while nude or while displaying specified anatomical areas, providing personal services for another person. Such businesses include, but are not limited to, modeling studios, body painting studios, wrestling studios, conversation parlors and theatrical performances or entertainment. 
    Adult video store means an establishment which has in excess of 50 percent of its stock-in-trade for sale or rental to the public or patrons, videocassettes or videotapes, having as a dominant theme an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
    Buttock means the anus and perineum of any person. 
    Massage means the manipulation of body muscle or tissue by rubbing, stroking, kneading, tapping or vibrating, through the use of a physical, mechanical or other device, of the body of another, for a fee. 
    Massage parlor means an establishment wherein private massage is practiced, used or made available as a principle use of the premises. 
    Nude modeling studio means any building, structure, premises or part thereof used primarily as a place which offers as its principal activity the providing of models to display specified anatomical areas for artists and photographers for a fee. 
    Protected use means a church, school or public park. 
    Public park means any park owned and maintained by the city. 
    School means a public or private school offering education to students enrolled in kindergarten or one or more grades of one through 12. 
    Sexual intercourse means fellatio, cunnilingus, anal intercourse and any other intrusion, however slight, of any part of a person's body, or of any object into the genital or anal openings of another's body. 
    Sodomy means sexual bestiality. 
    Specified anatomical areas means: 
(1)	Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.	Human genitalia and pubic region; 
b.	Buttock; or 
c.	Female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(2)	Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities means: 
(1)	The stimulation or arousal of human genitalia; 
(2)	Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; or 
(3)	Fondling or other erotic touching of human genitalia, pubic region, buttock or female breast. 
    Tattoo parlor means a business having as its principal activity the application or placing, by any method, of designs, letters, scrolls, figures, symbols or other marks upon or under the human skin with ink or any other substance resulting in the coloration of the skin by the aid of needles or any other instrument designed to touch or puncture the skin. 
(Ord. No. 1992-5, § 2, 5-18-1992; Code 1972, app. A-4, § A-4.2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-183. - Restrictions on location. 
    An adult business may be located in the city only in accordance with the following restrictions: 
(1)	All such businesses shall be limited to the area within the city more specifically described as follows: 
The west 52.1 rods (859.65 feet ) of the east half of the northeast quarter of Section 3, Town 2 South, Range 8 west, City of Springfield, Calhoun County, Michigan, lying north of the Penn Central Railroad. 
(2)	No adult business shall be located within 500 feet of a preexisting protected use. 
(Ord. No. 1992-5, § 3, 5-18-1992; Code 1972, app. A-4, § A-4.3) 
Sec. 8-184. - Miscellaneous requirements. 
(a)	The height, yard, lot area, lot width, building coverage, sign and parking requirements of an adult business shall conform to the requirements for the zone in which it is located. 
(b)	The distance between an adult business and a protected use shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the closest exterior wall of the adult business or building containing an adult business to the nearest property line of the protected use. 
(c)	No person shall reside in or permit any person to reside in the premises of an adult business. 
(Ord. No. 1992-5, § 4, 5-18-1992; Code 1972, app. A-4, § A-4.4) 
Sec. 8-185. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article regarding massage parlors shall not apply to hospitals, sanitariums, nursing homes or medical clinics, or to the offices of a physician, surgeon, chiropractor, osteopath or physical therapist, duly licensed by the state, or to barbershops or beauty salons in which massages are administered only to the scalp, face, neck or shoulders of patrons. 
(Ord. No. 1992-5, § 5, 5-18-1992; Code 1972, app. A-4, § A-4.5)

ARTICLE VIII. - AUTOMOTIVE REPAIR FACILITIES 

Sec. 8-301. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automotive repair facilities means a place of business that, for compensation, is engaged in the business of performing, or employs individuals who perform maintenance, diagnosis, vehicle body work, repair service, or BAIID service on a motor vehicle for compensation. The term does not include any of the following: 
(1)	An individual who engages only in the business of repairing the motor vehicles of a single commercial or industrial establishment or governmental agency. 
(2)	An individual who is repairing his or her own or a family member's car. 
(3)	A business that does not diagnosis the operation of a motor vehicle, does not remove parts from a motor vehicle to be re-machined and does not install finished machined or re-machined parts on a motor vehicle, not including a motor vehicle repair facility that engages in the business of performing or employing persons who perform vehicle body work. 
(4)	A BAIID facility described in Section 625k(14)(d) of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, MCL 257.625k. 
    BAIID service means the installation, removal, repair, or other servicing of breath alcohol ignition interlock devices. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-302. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in business as an automotive repair facility without first having obtained a license from the city under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-303. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a licensed required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time, and a copy of such resolution shall be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-304. - Adoption of state laws by reference. 
    All statutes of the state relating to automotive or motor vehicle service and repair, including specifically the Michigan Motor Vehicle Service and Repair Act, 1974 PA 300, as amended, MCL 257.1301 et seq. are hereby expressly incorporated into and made a part of this Code by reference, and no person shall violate any rule, law, or regulation contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-305. - Name or address change. 
    If a name or address of the automotive repair facility changes, not involving a change of ownership, the facility shall notify the city clerk in writing of the change. A new license must be obtained from the city clerk at that time. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-306. - Inspection of the premises. 
    A licensed facility or a facility required to be licensed under this article shall be open to inspection by the city manager and/or the city manager's designee during reasonable business hours. During reasonable business hours, the city manager and/or the city manager's designee may make periodic unannounced inspections of the premises, parts records, and parts inventories of facilities. A person who hinders, obstructs, or otherwise prevents an inspection is in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-307. - Injunctions. 
    If it appears that a person has engaged in, is engaging in, or is about to engage in with the operation of an automotive repair facility in violation of this article, the city may, with or without prior administrative proceedings having occurred under section 8-52 of this Code, bring an action to enjoin that operation. The action shall be brought in Calhoun County Circuit Court. The city shall not be required to post a bond in a court proceeding. In addition, the court may suspend or revoke a license issued under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Sec. 8-308. - Penalties and sanctions; municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions for each infraction as set out in section 1-56. 
(Ord. No. 2016-4, § 1, 12-5-2016) 
Chapter 10 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to acquire cemeteries, § 2.1(h); power of council to enact ordinances relative to cemeteries, § 5.3(q). 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 40. 
State Law reference- For cemeteries generally, MCL 128.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - City cemeteries to be only public burial grounds; burials restricted to public burial grounds. 
    All cemeteries now owned or which may hereafter be acquired by the city are hereby declared to be public burial grounds, and no person or organization of persons shall establish any other cemetery within the city. No person shall bury any body in any place in the city other than the public burial grounds. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 1; Code 1972, § 4-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - City cemetery designated. 
    The cemetery now owned by the city shall be known as "The Reese Cemetery." 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 2; Code 1972, § 4-2) 
Sec. 10-3. - Director of public works to promulgate rules and regulations. 
    The director of public works shall make rules and regulations to promote the general objects of this chapter and for the general improvement of the public burial grounds, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 8; Code 1972, § 4-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Establishment of grades. 
    The director of public works shall establish grade levels at which all graves in a given area shall be kept. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 5; Code 1972, § 4-4) 
Sec. 10-5. - Approval of monuments and plants. 
    The material and manner of erecting monuments, headstones and markers, the type, location and trimming of trees and shrubs, and the manner in which they are planted shall be subject to the approval of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 5; Code 1972, § 4-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Enclosures prohibited. 
    No person shall erect any enclosure in the nature of a fence, hedge or curbing upon any lot or plot. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 5; Code 1972, § 4-6) 
Sec. 10-7. - Director to plant trees and shrubs. 
    No trees or shrubs shall be planted or placed in the cemeteries of the city except by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 5; Code 1972, § 4-7) 
Sec. 10-8. - Trespassing; damaging cemetery property. 
    No person shall cut, remove, injure or carry away any tree, flower or other decorative planting; nor deface, injure, remove or displace any monument, marker or ornamental equipment; nor carry away, remove, destroy or injure any flowerpot, vase, flowers or other ornamentation; nor shall any person traverse any portion of the cemetery except upon ways provided for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 6; Code 1972, § 4-8) 
State Law reference- Willfully destroying or injuring tombs of the dead, MCL 750.387. 
Sec. 10-9. - Removal of ornamentation. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the director of public works, any tree, plant, shrub or ornamentation of any kind has become unsightly, dangerous or detrimental to the adjacent lot owners, or the public use of the cemetery, the director of public works may remove the tree, plant, shrub or ornamentation. 
(Ord. No. 1053-15, § 7; Code 1972, § 4-9) 
Secs. 10-10-10-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BURIALS 

Sec. 10-31. - Burials to be in accordance with state law and county health department regulations. 
    No person shall bury any body in the public burial grounds except in accordance with state law and the regulations of the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 3; Code 1972, § 4-21) 
State Law reference- Interment or other disposition, authorization required, duty of person in charge of premises, record, contents, MCL 333.2850. 
Sec. 10-32. - Only human bodies to be buried in public burial grounds. 
    No person shall bury any body except a human body in any public burial ground. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 3; Code 1972, § 4-22) 
Sec. 10-33. - Burials restricted to one body per grave; exception for infants. 
    No person shall bury more than one body in a single grave except in the case of infants, and then only in a single grave space. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 3; Code 1972, § 4-23) 
Sec. 10-34. - Approved underground vaults required for burials. 
    No burial shall be made except in underground vaults of construction approved by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 5; Code 1972, § 4-24) 
Sec. 10-35. - Burial right required. 
    No person shall bury any body in the public burial grounds without having purchased and paid for a burial right. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 3; Code 1972, § 4-25) 
Sec. 10-36. - Burials restricted to lot owner or family; exception. 
    Burial in any burial plot shall be restricted to the owner of such plot and the owner of the plot's immediate family, unless written authorization is obtained from the owner or the owner's heirs. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-26) 
Secs. 10-37-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOTS AND SERVICES 

Sec. 10-61. - Rates to be established by city council. 
    Lots and graves in the public burial grounds shall be sold and services shall be paid for at the rates established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-37) 
Sec. 10-62. - Burial rights certificate form. 
    Burial rights certificates shall be issued in such form as the director of public works shall prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-38) 
Sec. 10-63. - Issuance of burial rights certificate to vest full ownership rights; transferability. 
    A burial rights certificate shall entitle the person to whom it is issued to full ownership and control of the plot for which it was issued with the right to convey, or to transmit to such person's heirs and devisees in accordance with the state law. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-40) 
Sec. 10-64. - Inter vivos transfers to be made only upon full payment. 
    No inter vivos transfer shall be made of any burial rights certificate unless payment therefor has been made in full. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-41) 
Sec. 10-65. - Installment purchases; minimum terms; defaults. 
    Whenever any lot or plot in the public burial grounds is purchased on terms, the purchaser shall pay not less than 25 percent of the purchase price at the time of making the contract. The balance due on the contract shall be paid in monthly installments of not less than five percent of the total purchase price. In case of default, the entire balance shall become due and payable and interest shall be added on the unpaid balance at the rate of seven percent per annum, unless a new agreement of purchase shall be agreed upon between the purchaser and the public works director. In the event of default, the public works director may declare the contract forfeited and resell the unused portion of the lot or plot. 
(Ord. No. 1953-15, § 4; Code 1972, § 4-42) 
Sec. 10-66. - Maintenance of lots and plots generally. 
    The director of public works shall maintain the cemetery for the use and benefit of the lots and plots therein and for the use and benefit of the city in a manner conforming to all regulations of the city and state law. 
(Code 1972, § 4-43)

ARTICLE II. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Economic development corporations, MCL 125.1601 et seq. 

Sec. 12-31. - Application approved; article of incorporation. 
    The application of Harold D. Gestring and others dated November 7, 1983, and proposed articles of incorporation attached thereto are amended by changing the name of the corporation to The Economic Development Corporation of the City of Springfield, 1931 PA 327 (MCL 450.62 et seq.), by fixing the number of members of the board of directors at nine, and terms of office for six years, except of the directors first appointed, four shall be appointed for six years, one for five years, one for four years, one for three years, one for two years, and one for one year, establishing the date upon which the corporation shall become effective, setting forth the name of the newspaper in which these articles shall be published, setting forth the manner of adopting bylaws, and by amending the business address of Robert G. Peevers to read 1400 East Columbia Avenue, Battle Creek, Michigan, 49017, and as amended are hereby approved and shall read as follows: 
PROPOSED ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION 
NONPROFIT ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION 
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION FOR THE CITY OF SPRINGFIELD, MICHIGAN 
    These articles of incorporation are signed and acknowledged by the incorporators for the purpose of forming a nonprofit corporation under the provisions of 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1601 et seq.), as follows: 
ARTICLE I. 
    The name of the corporation is the Economic Development Corporation of the City of Springfield. 
ARTICLE II. 
    The corporation is organized pursuant to 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1601 et seq.). Its purposes will be to alleviate and prevent conditions of unemployment, to assist and retain local industries and commercial enterprises, to strengthen and revitalize the economy of the City of Springfield, to provide means and methods for the encouragement and assistance of industrial and commercial enterprises in locating and expanding in the City of Springfield, to encourage the location and expansion of commercial enterprises in the City of Springfield, more conveniently to provide needed services and facilities of the commercial enterprises of the City of Springfield and its residents and to accomplish the foregoing to do the following: 
(a)	To take, accept, hold and acquire by bequest, devise, gift, purchase, loan or lease any property, real, personal or mixed, whether tangible or intangible, without limitation as to kind, amount or value; 
(b)	To sell, convey, lease, rent, or make loans, grants or pledges of any such property, or any interest therein or proceeds therefrom, and to invest and reinvest the principal thereof and receipts therefrom, if any; 
(c)	To borrow money and to issue, sell or pledge its obligations and evidences of indebtedness and to mortgage its property to secure the payment thereof; 
(d)	To aid, assist and participate in clearing, rebuilding and rehabilitating blighted, or deteriorated areas or structures; 
(e)	To encourage, assist and participate in the preparation of plans, services, studies and recommendations; 
(f)	To guarantee undertakings, contracts or performances of others; 
(g)	To encourage citizen participation in housing and community improvements and improvement programs, and to disseminate information to the general public concerning the objectives and purposes of the corporation; 
(h)	To hold, improve by construction or otherwise, and to develop, clear, prepare and dispose of real property; 
(i)	To aid, assist and participate in the acquisition, rehabilitation or construction of improvements upon real estate, dwelling units or other structures or matters incident thereto; 
(j)	To enter into contracts with public authorities, individuals, corporations and other organizations in connection therewith; 
(k)	To carry on any activity for the purposes above stated, either directly or as agent, for or with public authorities, individuals, corporations or other organizations, or in whole or in part through or by means of public authorities, individuals, corporations or other organizations; 
(l)	In general, and subject to such limitations and conditions as are or may be prescribed by law, to exercise such other powers which now are or hereafter may be conferred by law upon a corporation organized under the above statutes and for the above purposes. 
ARTICLE III. 
    Location of the first registered office is: 601 Avenue A, Springfield, Michigan 49015. 
    The post office address of the first registered office is: 601 Avenue A, Springfield, Michigan 49015. 
ARTICLE IV. 
    The name of the first resident agent is: Carlene DeMaso, 601 Avenue A, Springfield, Michigan, 49015. 
ARTICLE V. 
    Said corporation is organized upon a nonstock basis. The amount of assets which said corporation possesses is: 
(1)	Real property: None 
(2)	Personal property: None 
    The corporation will be financed from donations, gifts, grants and devices, either solicited or unsolicited, obtained from public authorities, individuals, corporations and other organizations, by earnings from its activities, borrowings, and issuance of revenue bonds. 
ARTICLE VI. 
    The names and places of business of each of the incorporators are as follows: Adelbert E. Bishop, City of Springfield; Milford A. Mellon, City of Springfield; B. Carol Hinton, 309 North 20th Street, Springfield, Michigan, 49015; Robert G. Peevers, 1400 East Columbia Avenue, Battle Creek, Michigan, 49017; and Harold D. Gestring, 426 North 20th Street, Springfield, Michigan 49015. 
ARTICLE VII. 
    The board of directors shall consist of nine persons and shall be appointed by the mayor of the City of Springfield, with the advice and consent of the city council of the City of Springfield. These directors shall be appointed for six years, except of the directors first appointed, four shall be appointed for six years, one for five years, one for four years, one for three years, one for two years, and one for one year. 
ARTICLE VIII. 
    This corporation shall become effective on June 1, 1984. 
ARTICLE IX. 
    The term of the corporate existence is perpetual. 
ARTICLE X. 
    The regulation of the internal affairs of the corporation, including the distribution of assets on dissolution or final liquidation, is placed entirely with the board of directors or its successors, as provided in the bylaws of this corporation, subject, however, to the provisions of 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1601 et seq.). 
ARTICLE XI. 
    At the first meeting of the corporate board of directors, it shall adopt bylaws by corporate resolution. A majority of five members shall be necessary to adopt any bylaw or amended bylaw. Bylaws may thereafter be amended in the same manner. 
ARTICLE XII. 
    No part of the net earnings of the corporation shall inure to the benefit of any member, trustee, officer or director of the corporation, or any private individual (except that reasonable compensation may be paid for services rendered to or for the corporation affecting one or more of its purposes), and no member, trustee, officer or director of the corporation or any private individual shall be entitled to share in the distribution of any of the corporate assets on dissolution of the corporation. No substantial part of the activities of the corporation shall be the carrying on of propaganda, or otherwise attempting, to influence legislation, and the corporation shall not participate in or intervene in (including the publication or distribution of statements) any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office. Upon the dissolution of the corporation or the winding up of its affairs, all property and assets of the corporation shall be distributed exclusively to the City of Springfield, Michigan, or its successor. 
ARTICLE XIII. 
    These articles of incorporation shall be published in the Battle Creek Enquirer on adoption by resolution of the city council. 
    We, the incorporators, sign our names this 7th day of November, 1983.

(Ord. No. 1984-2, § 2; Code 1972, § 43/4-11) 
Sec. 12-32. - Incorporation authorized. 
    After the city approves a resolution approving the application to incorporate the economic development corporation and the resolution is in effect and is filed with the secretary of state pursuant to section 5 of the 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1605), the clerk shall incorporate the Economic Development Corporation pursuant to sections 28 to 36 of 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1628-125.1636). 
(Ord. No. 1984-2, § 2; Code 1972, § 43/4-12) 
Sec. 12-33. - Time limitation for corporation. 
    So far as permitted by the laws and statutes of the state, the term of existence of the economic development corporation shall be perpetual. 
(Ord. No. 1984-2, § 2; Code 1972, § 43/4-13) 
Sec. 12-34. - Limitation of action; right to question incorporation. 
    In accordance with section 31 of 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1631), the validity of the incorporation shall be conclusively presumed unless questioned in a court of competent jurisdiction within 60 days after filing of a certified copy with the secretary of state. The right exists to question the incorporation of the economic development corporation of the city as provided in section 31 of 1974 PA 338 (MCL 125.1631) and as stated in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1984-2, § 3; Code 1972, § 43/4-14) 
Secs. 12-35-12-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCE AUTHORITY[3] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-101 et seq. 
State Law reference- The tax increment finance authority act, MCL 125.1801 et seq. 

Sec. 12-61. - Adoption of 1980 PA 450 by reference. 
    A tax increment finance authority is hereby created and established pursuant to the terms and provisions of 1980 PA 450 (MCL 125.1801 et seq.), which Act is adopted by reference thereto by the city as this article, as herein modified. 
(Ord. No. 1985-5, § 4; Code 1972, § 43/4-21) 
Sec. 12-62. - Reference to terms in Act. 
    Reference in 1980 PA 450 (MCL 125.1801 et seq.) to "chief executive officer" shall mean the mayor of the city. References to "governing body of a municipality" shall mean the city council of the city. References to "municipality" shall mean the city. 
(Ord. No. 1985-5, § 4; Code 1972, § 43/4-22) 
Sec. 12-63. - Boundaries of the district. 
(a)	The boundaries of the tax increment finance district within which the authority shall exercise its powers are as follows:

thence east along the south right-of-way line of Avenue A to the southerly extension of the east right-of-way line of Easy Street; thence north to the north right-of-way line of Avenue A; thence in a westerly direction along the north right-of-way of Avenue A to the point of intersection with the east right-of-way line of Evergreen Road;
