(b)	The owner and/or occupant of any premises shall clean up and remove any scattered refuse resulting from the breakage, opening or handling of any container, plastic bag or receptacle placed by such owner or occupant for collection from the premises after the refuse has been scattered. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-8.4) 
State Law reference- Littering, MCL 752.901 et seq.; littering, MCL 324.8901 et seq. 
Sec. 36-90. - Vacant lots. 
    Any person owning or having a possessory interest in any lot or portion of land within the city, which is vacant or not constituting a premises, shall be responsible for the securing, collecting and disposal of refuse which may accumulate thereon by contracting with a person licensed in accord with the requirements of this article; or, by self-removal through proper collection and storage of refuse, transporting the refuse in a manner to prevent littering or any other nuisances, and depositing the refuse at an approved disposal area, in accordance with applicable local, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-8.5) 
Sec. 36-91. - Open burning prohibited. 
    No person shall kindle or maintain any open fire or authorize any such fire to be kindled or maintained on any premises without having obtained a permit or other proper authorization therefor from the public safety department. This restriction shall not apply to residential fireplaces or to the use of charcoal and similar materials for the purpose of food preparation. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-8.6) 
Sec. 36-92. - Scavenging. 
    After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, it shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge refuse left for disposal or rifle the refuse; and no person shall damage or destroy the bags or containers of refuse placed for storage. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-8.7) 
Secs. 36-93-36-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RATES, BILLING AND ASSESSMENTS FOR RESIDENTIAL PREMISES 

Sec. 36-111. - Establishing residential rates. 
    The city council shall establish by resolution all rates and fees for residential premises refuse collection. Such rates shall be subject to revision by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.1) 
Sec. 36-112. - Responsibility for payment. 
(a)	In the case of residential premises containing more than one dwelling unit which is billed separately for water and sewer charges by the city treasurer, such fees shall be billed to the person who is the customer of the city treasurer. In the case of residential premises containing more than one dwelling unit served by a single water and sewer bill, so that occupants or tenants cannot be billed separately by the treasurer's office, such fees as are prescribed by this article shall be billed to the customer of the single utility bill who shall be liable for the service fee for such premises. Owners and/or occupants of residential premises who are not customers of the city treasurer shall be billed individually. 
(b)	Although the occupant or person in possession of the residential premises may make arrangements with the city for payment of rates for the required refuse service, the owner of record, as title holder as reflected in the records of the city assessor, shall be responsible for all refuse collection charges for service to the owner's residential premises. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.2) 
Sec. 36-113. - Continuing service; occupancy. 
    Residential premises refuse collection and appropriate charges for service shall continue, regardless of the customer's response to the billing procedure, so long as the residential unit is deemed occupied. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises to advise the city or its contractor of any change in occupancy of the residential unit for purposes of service and billing. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.3) 
Sec. 36-114. - Exceptions to payment. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of any owner and/or occupant of residential premises to notify the city treasurer's office if such premises are being vacated between billing periods. It shall be the duty of any owner and/or occupant entering into any residential premises in the city to notify the city treasurer's office immediately to avoid delay in billing and collection procedures. 
(b)	No charge shall be levied on and no refuse collection shall be rendered to the owner and/or occupant of residential premises when such premises are temporarily vacated as established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.4) 
Sec. 36-115. - Elderly handicapped discount. 
    All elderly and handicapped persons shall receive a discount for residential curbside unlimited or backyard unlimited service by the city contractor as determined by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.5) 
Sec. 36-116. - Billing of service fee. 
    The service fee for removal of refuse by the city contractor shall be established by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.6) 
Sec. 36-117. - Billing procedures. 
    The following billing procedures shall be controlling as to residential premises refuse collection service: 
(1)	Statements shall be rendered bimonthly and be payable to the city at the office of the city treasurer and other locations as may be designated. 
(2)	The billing statement shall be payable on or before the due date shown on the statement. Payment date shall constitute the date upon which payment is received at the appropriate office. A late charge of ten percent of the unpaid bill shall be assessed on all bills paid more than 30 days after the due date. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.7) 
Sec. 36-118. - Charges to constitute lien on residential premises; assessment; payment. 
    The following provisions govern the attachment, collection and payment of liens constituted by charges for residential refuse collection: 
(1)	The charges for residential premises refuse collection shall constitute a lien on all such premises. 
(2)	In addition to the methods of collection and fees imposed in this article, the city treasurer shall, on June 30 and January 1, certify all unpaid charges for such service furnished to any premises which, as of these dates, have remained unpaid for a period of six months, to the city assessor who shall place the unpaid charges on a special assessment roll of the city, and shall be collected and enforced in the same manner as special assessments. 
(3)	If the city is properly notified that a tenant is responsible for residential refuse service charges, the city shall require a tenant deposit as established by resolution of the city council from time to time which shall be applied to the final bill upon termination of refuse service to such tenant. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-9.8) 
Sec. 36-119. - Additional services allowed; schedule for charges for additional services. 
    The city contractor shall be allowed to provide additional services to residential customers. Those additional services may include providing containers that are larger than 30 gallons and removal of yard waste that is greater than 50 pounds in weight or larger than four feet in length. Charges for any additional services not included in the services to be covered by the contract shall be a private transaction between the occupant of the residential premises and the city contractor. However, the city contractor shall be required to prepare written schedules of the charges for additional services and provide the schedule to the city clerk ten calendar days prior to instituting the charges provided for by the schedule. 
(Ord. No. 1987-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 7-9.9) 
Secs. 36-120-36-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CONTRACT; LICENSING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Licensing, § 8-31 et seq. 

Sec. 36-136. - Contract; residential premises. 
    The city council may, either by advertising for bids or otherwise, enter into an exclusive contract with the mutual consent of a contractor, which shall be licensed, or extend the term thereof, which such person as the city council may deem best able to collect and dispose of residential refuse in the city in accordance with the best interests of the city and its citizens. The contractor shall be the only person allowed to provide residential refuse collection and disposal services within the city or within the boundaries prescribed by the limitations of this article. The contract documents shall contain provisions that the city contractor shall collect and dispose of refuse from all residential premises in the city in full compliance with this article and applicable local, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.1) 
Sec. 36-137. - Collection and disposal as business; license required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of collection, transportation or disposal of refuse in the city without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this division. All persons, other than persons disposing of such persons' own refuse, shall obtain a license and be subject to the provisions of this division as though such persons were engaged in the business of collecting, transporting or disposing of refuse in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.2) 
Sec. 36-138. - License application. 
    Application for a license under this article shall be made in writing to the city clerk's office upon forms furnished by such office and each applicant in such application shall state such applicant's residence and business address, the number, year and style of conveyances and vehicles to be used and owned by the applicant, the engine numbers of the motor vehicles and the places where such vehicles are parked overnight. Such application shall also contain an agreement by the applicant to obey, abide by and comply with all provisions of this article and all other laws, ordinances, rules and regulations applicable to the conduct of such business now in force or which may hereafter be adopted. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.3) 
Sec. 36-139. - Indemnification. 
    A licensee shall pay any judgment which may be obtained against the city, alone or jointly with such licensee, on account of any injury or damage to persons or to property by reason of any license granted under this division. The licensee shall intervene and defend any such suit or action upon written notice thereof given by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.5) 
Sec. 36-140. - Issuance of license. 
    If the applicant has complied with all of the provisions of this division and all provisions of this Code applicable to the applicant and business for which the license is made, the city clerk shall issue the license provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.7) 
Sec. 36-141. - Fee, bonding and insurance requirements. 
    Every person who engages in the business of collection, transportation or disposal of refuse in the city shall meet fee requirements of this article and any bonding and insurance requirements imposed by the city manager. The license year shall be from May 1 to the succeeding April 30 and the fee shall be payable in advance. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.9) 
Sec. 36-142. - Compliance of licensee. 
    The licensee shall at all times comply with all requirements of this division and all rules and regulations issued pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.10) 
Sec. 36-143. - License denial, suspension and revocation. 
(a)	The city manager may deny, suspend or revoke any license granted under this division for cause after an informal hearing is requested in writing by the affected licensee. 
(b)	Any licensee aggrieved by a final decision of the city manager shall have the right to a hearing before the city council provided that a written request is filed with the city clerk within five days after receipt of notice of the city manager's decision. During the pendency of any such appeal, the final determination of the city manager shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.11) 
Sec. 36-144. - Vehicle maintenance. 
    Vehicles used in the transportation of refuse shall be kept clean and in good repair. The hauling body shall be watertight and completely enclosed on all sides. Vehicles shall be maintained and operated so that no portion of the vehicles' contents are spilled or allowed to remain on any public highway. All vehicles shall be cleaned at intervals frequent enough to maintain the unit in a sanitary condition and as free from disagreeable odor as possible to prevent nuisance or vermin attraction. A vehicle that fails to meet the requirements of this article shall be removed from service until it complies or its use shall be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.12) 
Sec. 36-145. - Vehicle operation; collection practices. 
    The following provisions govern the operation of vehicles used in the transportation of refuse: 
(1)	The openings of each vehicle shall be closed and doors or covers shall be secured by an adequate latch or restraining mechanism to keep them closed while transporting refuse. The driver and licensee shall see that the available cover is in the proper position. A special covering shall be used where conditions require control of odor, vermin, liquids, dust or smoke. 
(2)	Each vehicle shall be loaded in a manner to minimize the spilling of materials. It shall be the duty of contractors to transfer the contents of all containers for which they have contracted with a customer into vehicles licensed under this article, using care to avoid spilling any garbage, rubbish or waste. It shall be the duty of the operator or the operator's designated agent to clean up all garbage or rubbish spilled during collection and completely empty the containers and replace the lids thereon. 
(3)	Where spillage does occur from a refuse transporting unit, the material shall be picked up by the operator or a designated agent as soon as possible and the area suitably cleaned. 
(4)	Each vehicle, when transporting refuse, shall be emptied only in approved disposal areas. 
(5)	No vehicle shall be parked in a residential area longer than necessary to collect refuse unless it is parked not less than 500 feet from adjacent residences. The 500-foot requirement does not apply to vehicles parked at one's own residence if a nuisance is not created. Vehicles shall not be parked, stored or established at any location so as to cause a hazard to health or at any residentially zoned location so as to cause a nuisance. 
(6)	All licensees shall provide a telephone number to receive complaints through at least normal daytime business hours and provide someone to answer and resolve such complaints within 24 hours. 
(7)	Licensees collecting in early morning hours shall use every precaution to prevent unnecessary noise. 
(8)	The licensee shall not damage cans which are owned by customers or other property while making collections and shall return cans to their location or designated place. 
(9)	The licensee servicing residential customers shall provide each customer a minimum of one pickup per week in accordance with a pickup schedule approved by the city council. 
(10)	No refuse shall be collected from residential premises in the city except between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.13) 
Sec. 36-146. - Vehicle requirements. 
    All vehicles of any licensee carrying refuse under this article shall have on both sides thereof a sign containing the name of the licensee, with the telephone number and the number of the vehicle, all of which shall be painted thereon in plain and unobscured letters not less than four inches in height. 
(Ord. No. 1985-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 7-10.6) 
Secs. 36-147-36-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESOURCE RECOVERY FACILITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-171. - Defined. 
    For purposes of this article, a "resource recovery facility" is defined as set out in 1994 PA 451 (MCL 324.11505). 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-211) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 36-172. - Adoption of state laws by reference. 
    All statutes of the state relating to waste recycling and recovery are hereby expressly incorporated into and made a part of this Code by reference and no person shall violate any rule, law or regulation contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-214) 
Sec. 36-173. - Infestation by vermin and insects prohibited. 
    No person who is the owner, occupant or operator of a resource recovery facility shall permit any rats, other vermin, flies, mosquitoes or other disease-bearing or noisome insects of any kind to infest or breed in or upon the premises where such facility is conducted. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-216) 
Secs. 36-174-36-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 36-191. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a resource recovery facility operation without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-212) 
Sec. 36-192. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and a copy of such resolution shall always be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-213) 
Sec. 36-193. - Application; contents. 
    The application for a license required by this article shall be signed by the applicant if an individual, by a partner if a partnership, and by the president or executive officer if a corporation, showing the following: 
(1)	The full name, permanent residence and local address of the applicant; 
(2)	The name of the firm or corporation represented, if any, together with the address of the central or district office of such firm or corporation; 
(3)	The address or location of the places within the city at which the applicant proposes to engage in business; 
(4)	If a corporation, the state of incorporation; 
(5)	The length of time for which the license is desired; 
(6)	Whether the business has previously been licensed under this article and if so, the date of the last license, and whether this application is a renewal; 
(7)	The general description of the type of business to be operated; 
(8)	Such other information as to the identity or character of the persons managing the business as the city clerk may deem proper to fulfill the purpose of this article and the protection of the public good; 
(9)	An affidavit of the applicant to the truth of the statements in the application; 
(10)	Such other information as the city may deem necessary and appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-218) 
Sec. 36-194. - Issuance of license. 
    Upon receipt of the application for a license required by this article, payment of the required fee and confirmation by the city clerk that the applicant is otherwise in compliance with city ordinances, the city clerk shall issue a license to operate as a resource recovery facility. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-219) 
Sec. 36-195. - Contents of license. 
    Each license issued pursuant to this article shall contain the following: 
(1)	The date of issuance; 
(2)	The nature of the business to be conducted under the license; 
(3)	The amount of fee paid; 
(4)	The expiration date; 
(5)	The place where the business may be conducted; and 
(6)	The name of the person authorized to conduct the business. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-220) 
Sec. 36-196. - Expiration of license. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this article shall expire on June 30 and may be renewed at that time. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1, § 1, 3-4-1996; Code 1972, § 8-217) 
Chapter 38 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- General power of city relative to special assessments, § 11.4 et seq. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-9(10); administration, ch. 2; community development, ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 40. 
State Law reference- Special assessments for public improvements, MCL 68.31 et seq.; higher interest rates permitted when there are obligations in anticipation of special assessments, MCL 133.9; public improvement or public building, MCL 141.261 et seq.; notices and hearings, MCL 211.741 et seq.; deferment of special assessment for homesteads, MCL 211.761 et seq. 

Sec. 38-1. - "Public improvement" defined. 
    The term "public improvement" as used in this chapter shall include the reconstruction in whole or in part of any structure or work as well as the original construction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-2. - Financing the cost of public improvements. 
    Construction of public improvements in the city in excess of the amount provided for in the annual appropriation resolution shall be paid for by one or more of the following methods or by such other method as may be permitted by state law: 
(1)	Federal or state participation individually or combined with any or all other methods of financing with the city. 
(2)	Special assessment including bond issue. 
(3)	Revenue bond issue. 
(4)	Advance financing by property owners. 
(5)	Tax increment bonds. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-2) 
Sec. 38-3. - City to construct public improvements. 
    The city shall construct and repair, or cause to be constructed and repaired, all public improvements deemed necessary for the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-3) 
Sec. 38-4. - Special assessment procedure. 
    The making and financing of public improvements in the city by the special assessment method shall be governed by this chapter and all proceedings therefor shall be taken in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4) 
Sec. 38-5. - Determination of cost. 
    The cost of surveys, maps, drawings, plans and specifications for a public improvement and all expenses incident to the proceedings for the making of such improvement, the making and collecting of the special assessments therefor, and the issuance of bonds in anticipation of such special assessments, shall be deemed a part of the cost of such improvement. Whenever any property is acquired by condemnation, or otherwise, for the purpose of any public improvement, all or any part of the cost thereof may be included as a part of the cost of such improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.1) 
Sec. 38-6. - Assessment may be based on estimated cost. 
    Any assessment may be made upon the basis of the estimated cost of the improvement if the actual cost has not been definitely determined. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.2) 
Sec. 38-7. - Petition generally. 
    A petition addressed to the city council may be filed with the city clerk requesting the city council to make a public improvement therein described and to assess the cost thereof, or such part of the cost as the city council shall decide, to benefited lands comprising a special assessment district to be determined by the city council. Any petition so filed may be in one or more parts and shall be signed by the owners of lands having at least 50 percent of the privately owned frontage abutting upon the proposed improvement. The city clerk shall not present to the city council any petition not so signed. A purchaser of a land contract shall be deemed the owner of such land. Such petition, in addition to the signatures of the owners, shall contain a brief description of the property owned by the respective signers thereof. The genuineness of the signatures on each petition or part thereof shall be verified by the affidavit of the circulator. Any such petition shall not be mandatory upon the city council, but shall be advisory only, and in no event shall such petition be deemed jurisdictional. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.3) 
Sec. 38-8. - Authority of council to make public improvements; initial procedure. 
(a)	Irrespective of whether or not a petition shall have been filed in accordance with section 38-7, the city council may determine to make any public improvement and to defray the whole or any part of the cost thereof by special assessment upon property especially benefited thereby. The city council shall, by resolution, declare its intention to do so, stating therein the nature and the route or location of the proposed improvement and the lands and premises proposed to be included in the special assessment district and assessed therefor, and shall cause to be prepared and submitted to the city council, the following: 
(1)	A map or drawing showing the route or location of such proposed improvement and such proposed special assessment district. 
(2)	Plans and specifications for such proposed improvement. 
(3)	An estimate of the cost thereof. 
(b)	Upon the submission of the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate required by subsection (a) of this section, the city council shall, if it desires to proceed with the making of the improvement and the special assessments therefor, so declare by resolution. The city council by such resolution shall order the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate to be filed in the office of the city clerk for public examination, shall determine the necessity of such improvement, shall state the estimated cost thereof and what part or proportion, if less than all, shall be paid by special assessment and what part or proportion, if any, shall be a general obligation of the city, shall specify the number of installments in which assessments may be paid, and shall designate the district or lands and premises upon which the special assessments shall be levied. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.4) 
Sec. 38-9. - Hearing; notice. 
(a)	Before finally determining to make the improvement and the special assessments therefor, the city council shall hold a public hearing at a time and place to be fixed by the city council. At such hearing, the council shall hear and consider any objections which may be submitted by any interested person with respect to the making of such improvement and the assessing to the designated special assessment district of all or that part of the cost of the improvement which the city council has proposed to so assess. 
(b)	The city council shall cause notice of such hearing to be given by the city clerk not less than ten days prior to the date of such hearing, by publication thereof at least once in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, and by sending by first class U.S. Mail, postage thereon fully prepaid, a copy of such notice addressed to each person in whose name any land in the special assessment district is assessed on the last preceding tax assessment roll of the city, at such person's last known address, and also (if such address is different from the address of the premises in the district) a copy of such notice addressed to the "occupant" of each such premises which has an address served by U.S. Mail. Such notice shall specify the improvement, describe the district, state the estimated cost and the division thereof as between the district and the city at large, and give notice that the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate of the improvement are on file with the city clerk for public examination. Such notice shall also comply with the requirements of 1962 PA 162 (MCL 211.741 et seq.). 
(c)	At the time of such hearing, or any adjournment thereof, which may be without further notice, the city council shall hear and consider such objections as are submitted and shall record in the minutes of such meeting the names of all persons objecting, the properties owned by them, and the nature of such persons' objections. The city council, without further notice, may revise, correct, amend or change the map or drawing, plans, specifications, estimate and/or district; provided that no property shall be added to the district until notice is given as provided in subsection (b) of this section or by personal service upon the owners thereof and a hearing afforded such owners. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.5) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearing notice, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 38-10. - Adoption of resolution to make improvement; contents. 
    After the hearing provided for in section 38-9, if the city council desires to proceed with the making of the improvement and the special assessments therefor, it shall adopt a resolution approving the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate as originally presented or as revised, corrected, amended or changed, determining to make the improvement, designating the lands and premises constituting the special assessment district therefor, stating what part of the cost of the improvement, if any, shall be assumed and paid from the general funds of the city and directing that the remainder be assessed in accordance with benefits to the lands and premises constituting such special assessment district, specifying the number of installments in which the assessments shall be payable, and ordering the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll for all or that part of the cost to be so assessed; provided that if prior to the adoption of such resolution, written objections to the improvement have been filed by more than 50 percent of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed for the improvement, or in the case of a paving or similar improvement, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed, shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, then such resolution shall not be adopted and such improvement shall not be made, except in case of sidewalk construction, without the affirmative vote of five members of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.6) 
Sec. 38-11. - Special assessment roll-Preparation; filing; certificate. 
(a)	The city assessor shall thereupon, after the adoption of the resolution so directing, as provided for in section 38-10, prepare the special assessment roll in which shall be entered and described all the lands and premises to be assessed, with the names of the respective owners thereof, if known, and the amount to be assessed against each such parcel of land or premises. Such amount shall be such relative portion of the whole sum to be levied against all the lands and premises in the special assessment district as the benefit to such parcel of land or premises bears to the total benefits to all the lands and premises in the special assessment district. There shall also be entered upon such roll the amount which has been assumed by the city at large, if any. 
(b)	When the city assessor shall have completed the assessment roll, the assessor shall file the assessment roll in the office of the city clerk, after first having affixed thereto a certificate stating that it was made pursuant to a resolution of the city council adopted on a specified date and that in making such assessment roll the city assessor has, according to the assessor's best judgment, conformed in all respects to such resolution, this chapter and the Charter of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.7) 
Sec. 38-12. - Same-Hearing; notice. 
(a)	Before confirming any assessment roll, the city council shall appoint a time and place when it will meet and review the assessment roll and hear any objections thereto. The city council shall cause notice of such hearing and of the filing of such assessment roll to be given by the city clerk not less than ten days prior to the date of such hearing, by publication thereof at least once in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, and by sending by first class U.S. Mail, postage thereon fully prepaid, a copy of such notice addressed to each person in whose name any land is assessed on such roll, at such person's last known address, and also (if such address is different from the address of the premises in the district) a copy of such notice addressed to the "occupant" of each such premises which has an address served by U.S. Mail. Such notice shall also comply with the requirements of 1962 PA 162 (MCL 211.741 et seq.). 
(b)	The city council shall meet at the appointed time and place and at such meeting or any adjourned meeting (which may be without further notice), shall review the special assessment roll and hear and consider any objections thereto, and shall record in the minutes of such meeting the names of all persons who objected to such roll, the properties owned by such person's, and the nature of such person's objections. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.8) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notice and hearing, MCL 211.741. 
Sec. 38-13. - Same-Confirmation. 
(a)	After the hearing on the special assessment roll, provided for in section 38-12, the city council by resolution may confirm the special assessment roll, or may correct it as to any matter appearing therein and confirm it as so corrected, or may refer it back to the city assessor for revision, or may annul it and direct a new roll to be made. No special assessment roll shall be confirmed except with the affirmative vote of at least five members of the city council. If, at or prior to final confirmation of any special assessment roll, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of privately owned real property to be assessed thereon, or in the case of paving or similar improvement, more than 50 percent of the number of owners of frontage to be assessed thereon, shall object in writing to the proposed improvement, the special assessment roll shall not be confirmed, except in case of sidewalk construction, without the affirmative vote of five members of the city council. When a special assessment roll shall be confirmed, the city clerk shall endorse thereon the date of confirmation. After such confirmation, the special assessment roll and all assessments therein shall be final and conclusive. 
(b)	No work shall be commenced on any public improvement to be financed in whole or in part by special assessment until after confirmation of the special assessment roll therefor, nor shall any confirmation, except for legal, engineering, administrative and other services required for the preparation of the map or drawing, plans, specifications and cost estimate for the improvement and the taking of necessary proceedings, including the making of the special assessment roll, for the levying of the special assessments. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.9) 
Sec. 38-14. - Payment of special assessments. 
(a)	Special assessments may be made payable in one or more installments, as determined by the city council, but such installments may not exceed five in the case of sidewalk improvements, 15 in the case of paving or similar street improvements, and 20 in the case of water, storm sewer, sanitary sewer or other improvements. The first installment shall be due at such time after confirmation as the city council shall provide and the several subsequent installments shall be due at intervals of 12 months from the due date of the first installment. The amount of each installment, if more than one, need not be extended upon the special assessment roll until after confirmation. All installments not paid by a date to be fixed by the city council shall bear interest thereafter at the rate of one-half of one percent for each month or fraction thereof that the special assessment shall remain unpaid prior to their transfer to the city tax roll. Such accrued interest on all unpaid installments shall be due and payable annually on the due dates of the respective installments. Any one or more installments may be paid at any time before due together with accrued interest on such installments. 
(b)	If any installment is not paid when due, then the installment shall be deemed to be delinquent, and there shall be collected thereon, in addition to interest as provided in subsection (a) of this section, a collection fee of one percent and a penalty of two percent of such installment. In case any assessment or any installment thereof shall remain unpaid on the first Monday of May following the date when the installment became delinquent, the installment shall be reported unpaid by the city treasurer to the city council, and such delinquent assessments, together with all accrued interest, shall be transferred and reassessed on the next annual city tax roll in a column headed "special assessments" with a penalty of four percent upon such total amount added thereto, and when so transferred and reassessed upon such tax roll, shall be collected in all respects as provided for the collection of city taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.10) 
Sec. 38-15. - Lien of city upon property assessed. 
(a)	Special assessments and all interest, charges and penalties thereon, from the date of confirmation of the roll and until paid, shall be and remain a lien upon the property assessed of the same character and effect as the lien created by general law for the state and county taxes and by the city Charter for city taxes. 
(b)	No judgment or decree, nor any act of the city council vacating a special assessment shall destroy or impair the lien of the city upon the property assessed, for such amount of the assessment as may be equitably charged against the property, or as by a regular mode of proceeding might be lawfully assessed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.11) 
Sec. 38-16. - Collection of special assessments. 
(a)	When any special assessment shall be confirmed, the city council shall direct the assessment so made in the special assessment roll to be collected. The assessor shall thereupon deliver to the city treasurer such special assessment roll to which the assessor shall attach a warrant commanding the city treasurer to collect from each of the persons assessed in such roll the amount of money assessed to and set opposite such person's name therein. Upon receiving such special assessment roll and warrant, the city treasurer shall proceed to collect the several amounts assessed therein. 
(b)	In addition to any other remedies and without impairing the lien therefor, any delinquent special assessment together with interest and penalties may be collected in an action in the name of the city against the person assessed, in any court having jurisdiction. If in any such action it shall appear that by reason of any irregularities or informalities the assessment has not been properly made against the defendant or upon the premises sought to be charged, the court may, nevertheless, on satisfactory proof that expense has been incurred by the city, which is a proper charge against the defendant or the premises in question, render judgment for the amount properly chargeable against such defendant or upon such premises. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.12) 
Sec. 38-17. - Procedure when lot or parcel of land is divided after confirmation of special assessment. 
    Should any lot or parcel of land be divided after a special assessment thereon has been confirmed and before the collection thereof, the city council may require the city assessor to apportion the uncollected amounts upon the several parts of such lot or parcel of land. The report of such apportionment when confirmed shall be conclusive upon all parties, provided that before such confirmation, notice of hearing shall be given to all the interested parties by personal service or by publication and mailing as provided in case of an original assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.13) 
Sec. 38-18. - When additional pro rata assessments may be made. 
    Additional pro rata assessments may be made when any special assessment roll proves insufficient to pay for the improvement for which it was levied and the expenses incidental thereto, or insufficient to pay the principal and interest on bonds issued in anticipation of such assessment roll; provided that the additional pro rata assessment shall not exceed ten percent of the assessment as originally confirmed, unless a meeting of the city council is held to review such additional assessment, for which meeting notices shall be published and mailed as provided in the case of review of the original special assessment roll. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.14) 
Sec. 38-19. - Power of council to make new assessment where original declared invalid or illegal. 
    Whenever any special assessment roll shall, in the opinion of the city council, be invalid by reason or irregularity or informality in the proceedings, or if any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge such assessment to be illegal, the city council shall, whether the improvement shall have been made or not, or whether any part of the assessment shall have been paid or not, have power to cause a new assessment to be made for the same purpose for which the former assessment was made. All proceedings on such reassessment and for the collection thereof shall be conducted in the same manner as provided for in the original assessment except as to corrections in the proceedings required to make the assessment legal. Whenever any sum or part thereof, levied upon any property in the assessment so set aside, has been paid and not refunded, the payment so made shall be applied upon the reassessment. If the payments exceed the amount of the reassessment, refunds shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.15) 
Sec. 38-20. - Special assessment account. 
    Moneys raised by special assessments for any public improvement shall be credited to a special assessment account and shall be used to pay for the costs of the improvement for which the assessment was levied and for expenses incidental thereto, to repay any principal and interest on money borrowed therefor, and to refund excessive assessments. The excess by which any special assessment proves larger than the actual cost of the improvement and expense incidental thereto may be placed in the general fund of the city if such excess is five percent or less of the assessment, but should the assessment prove larger than necessary by more than five percent, the entire excess shall be refunded on a pro rata basis to the owners of the property assessed. Such refund shall be made by credit against future unpaid installments to the extent such installments then exist and the balance of such refund shall be in cash. No refunds may be made which contravene the provisions or any outstanding evidence of indebtedness secured in whole or in part by such special assessment. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.16) 
Sec. 38-21. - Procedure when expense incurred by city relative to single premises. 
    When any expense shall have been incurred by the city upon or in respect to any single premises, which expense is chargeable against such premises and the owner thereof under the provisions of the Charter or any ordinance of the city or law of the state, and is not of that class required to be prorated among the several lots and parcels of land in a special assessment district, an account of the labor, material and service for which such expense was incurred, with a description of the premises upon or in respect to which the expense was incurred, and the name of the owner, if known, shall be reported to the city treasurer, who shall immediately charge and bill the owner, if known. If the city treasurer finds that such amount is not otherwise collectible, the city treasurer shall report such information to the city council which may direct the city assessor to prepare a special assessment roll covering all such charges reported to it, together with a penalty of ten percent. Such roll shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall present the assessment roll to the city council. Thereafter, the same proceedings shall be followed in respect to such special assessment roll as are provided in section 38-11 and subsequent sections of this chapter and all the provisions of such sections with reference to special assessments generally shall apply to special assessments under this section, insofar as such provisions may be applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.17) 
Sec. 38-22. - No lands exempted from assessment; exception. 
    No lands in a special assessment district, which are benefited by the improvement therein, shall be exempt from assessment, but if the lands are owned by a public or other corporation exempt by law from the payment of special assessments, then the special assessments against such lands, or the installments thereof, may be paid by the city as the assessments become due or may be paid in advance of the assessments' due dates or may be paid by the exempt unit by special agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-4.18) 
Sec. 38-23. - Advance financing by property owners. 
    After determining the estimated cost and the proportion thereof to be defrayed by the city at large, the city council may order any public improvement, which is not included in the current year's construction program, to be made or constructed, in any case when the improvement has been petitioned for by all of the owners of property within the district to be affected or which shall constitute a special assessment district for the payment of the cost of such improvement; provided that, prior to the commencement of work on the improvement petitioned for, 100 percent of the total estimated cost and expense of such improvement according to the estimates of the cost thereof and the special assessment roll based thereon shall have been deposited with the city treasurer by the property owners within the district to be affected or constituting such special assessment district. In all cases where the total cost of any improvement has been deposited with the city treasurer prior to commencement of work thereon, the assessment roll and each assessment appearing thereon shall immediately, upon confirmation of such roll, be marked paid. In doing any work authorized and financed under the provisions of this section, the city engineer shall keep an accurate record of the cost and expense thereof and, upon completion of the work, shall report such cost and expense to the city council which shall, thereupon, authorize and direct that the amount, if any, of such money so deposited with the city treasurer which is in excess of the actual cost and expense of the improvement made shall be repaid by the city treasurer to those persons making such deposit, pro rata according to the several amounts deposited by such persons. The city council shall report to the city treasurer the city's share, if any, of the cost and expense of such improvements, as determined by the council under the provisions of chapter 40, article II, and shall direct that repayment of such city's share shall be made in one lump sum, or in five equal annual installments to the person making such deposits. Such lump sum payments or the first of such installments shall be paid on or before the 90th day of the fiscal year following the completion of the work. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-5) 
Sec. 38-24. - Sidewalks. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, proceedings for the construction of sidewalks and licensing of sidewalk contractors shall be initiated and continued in the manner set forth in and subject to the provisions of chapter 40, articles II and III. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-6) 
Sec. 38-25. - Streets-Construction proceedings. 
    Proceedings for the construction of streets, courts or alleys and the financing thereof within the city may be commenced by resolution of the city council or by an initiatory petition signed by property owners. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7) 
Sec. 38-26. - Same-Costs. 
    The city council may cause a street, court or alley to be improved and the cost thereof financed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.1) 
Sec. 38-27. - Same-"Cost" defined. 
    The term "cost," when referring to the cost of any improvement, shall include the cost of surveys, plans, land, rights-of-way, preparation of subgrade, excavation, fine grading, outlawn, base, pavement, landscaping, necessary replacement of repair of existing improvements, headers, catchbasins, water service replacement, general engineering expense, accounting, financing, printing, advertising, legal, and all other costs incident to the making of such improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-28. - Same-Recessed parking; cost of construction. 
    In case of recess parking construction, the adjacent property owners may be required 100 percent of the cost of the recessed construction. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.3) 
Sec. 38-29. - Same-Cost assessment. 
    In all street construction, the city shall pay from its proper funds at least one-third of the entire cost of street construction and the benefiting property owner shall pay not more than two-thirds of the entire cost including the cost of driveway approaches; provided, however, that benefiting property owners shall pay and shall be assessed for 100 percent of the cost of construction for curbs and gutters, except for the owners of corner lots who shall be assessed in accordance with section 38-31. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.4) 
Sec. 38-30. - Same-Contract for construction of street on tentative plat. 
    A contract for the construction of a street, where such street is a part of the tentative plat not yet put on public record, shall be performed in accordance with chapter 26, article III. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.5) 
Sec. 38-31. - Same-City to pay 50 percent of the cost of the special assessment levied against the longer of two sides of any platted corner lot. 
    The city shall pay 50 percent of the cost of the special assessment levied against the longer of the two sides of any platted corner lot for the payment of public improvements authorized by this Code. The property owners shall pay the balance of the cost of the special assessment levied against any platted corner lot. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-7.6) 
Sec. 38-32. - Sewers-Construction proceedings. 
    Proceedings for the construction of sewers and the financing thereof may be commenced by resolution of the city council or by an initiatory petition signed by property owners. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-8) 
Sec. 38-33. - Same-Authority of council. 
    The city council may cause a sewer or an extension of a sewer to be laid and the cost thereof to be financed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-8.1) 
Sec. 38-34. - Same-Cost assessment. 
    In all sewer construction, the city shall pay from its proper funds 100 percent of the cost of any sewer in any street, alley or easement exceeding the cost of the eight-inch sewer, in the case of a sanitary sewer, and a 12-inch sewer, in the case of a storm sewer. In the case of trunk sewers, the city may create a trunk sewer assessment district and assess two-thirds of the cost of all such sewers, exceeding the cost of an eight-inch sewer, in the case of a sanitary sewer, and a 12-inch sewer, in the case of a storm sewer, against the property benefited by the trunk sewer. The city shall pay from its proper funds the balance of the cost thereof, except that, with respect to the assessment to be borne by any exempt property, the city shall pay the entire cost. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-8.2) 
Sec. 38-35. - Driveway culverts. 
(a)	All pipe culverts, where deemed necessary for the public health and safety, shall be laid, constructed and repaired by the city, excepting as may be provided for in this chapter. Culverts may be ordered under private driveway approaches, where deemed necessary, by resolution of the city council. 
(b)	All pipe culverts for private driveway approaches laid, constructed and repaired shall be of corrugated iron pipe, cast iron pipe, or concrete culvert pipe. 
(c)	The cost of a 12-inch pipe and materials necessary to install the culvert shall be paid for by the owner. If a size larger than 12 inches is required, the city shall pay the difference in cost between the larger size required and the cost of a 12-inch culvert. The city shall pay the cost of all labor required to install culverts. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-9) 
Sec. 38-36. - Water mains. 
    In all water main construction, the city shall pay from its proper funds 100 percent of the cost of any water main in any street, alley or easement exceeding the cost of a six-inch main. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-10) 
Sec. 38-37. - Off-street parking lots. 
    Off-street parking lots, deemed by the city council to be necessary to the public convenience and safety, may be established, constructed and maintained by the city. If the city council shall determine to defray the cost of any such parking lot by special assessments upon the property benefited by the establishment and maintenance of any such parking lot, the procedures therefor shall be those established by this chapter. In determining the special assessment district benefited by the establishment and maintenance of any off-street parking lot, such district shall not be limited to properties abutting upon or adjacent to such parking lot, but may include properties within an area which, in the opinion of the city council, may derive benefit from the establishment and maintenance of such parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-11) 
Cross reference- Stopping, standing and parking, § 46-31 et seq. 
Sec. 38-38. - Separability of invalid provisions. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this chapter is, for any reason, held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate distinct and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1991-2; Code 1972, § 13-12) 
Chapter 40 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 40-1-40-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK REPAIRS 

Sec. 40-31. - "Sidewalk repair" defined. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "sidewalk repair" shall mean any reconstruction work of existing concrete sidewalks including replacement, relaying, patching, filling to grade or grading that may be required to bring the existing sidewalk to a condition satisfactory for public use. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 40-32. - Permit required for construction and repair. 
    No sidewalk shall be constructed or repaired without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-18) 
Sec. 40-33. - Permit fee. 
    The fee for a permit required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and a copy of such resolution shall always be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Ord. No. 1981-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 14-19) 
Sec. 40-34. - Property owner may contract work or do work. 
    The owner of property adjacent to a proposed sidewalk may contract with a licensed sidewalk builder to have the sidewalk constructed, or the owner of property adjacent to a proposed sidewalk may construct the sidewalk upon obtaining a permit from the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-20) 
Sec. 40-35. - Construction and repairs to conform to approved grades and specifications. 
    All sidewalks constructed or repaired shall be of concrete and in strict conformity with the grades and specifications adopted or approved by the city engineer and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-21) 
Sec. 40-36. - City engineer to establish line and grade; record. 
    Wherever sidewalks are ordered constructed on any street or any part thereof, or where a permit has been issued for the construction of a sidewalk, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to indicate the sidewalk line and grade by setting stakes. A record of the line and grade shall be kept in the city engineer's office. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-22) 
Sec. 40-37. - Acceptance of sidewalks in new subdivisions; prerequisites. 
    The city may accept a sidewalk as part of a public right-of-way where a sidewalk is constructed in a street shown on a tentative plat given tentative approval by the city, but not at that time put on public record if the following conditions are met: 
(1)	A special permit is given by the city; 
(2)	The city is paid for the services of a city inspector to inspect the sidewalk or to supervise the construction thereof insofar as is necessary to ensure that such construction is in accordance with plans and specifications adopted or approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-23) 
Sec. 40-38. - Rebate of construction costs upon acceptance by city. 
    When the construction of a sidewalk has been completed and has been inspected and approved by the city engineer, the owner of the property shall be entitled to receive from the city a rebate of $0.05 per square foot for any sidewalk accepted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-24) 
Sec. 40-39. - Initiation of sidewalk repairs. 
    The repair of any sidewalk may be initiated by a resolution adopted by the city council ordering the work done or by a written request of the owner of the property affected. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-25) 
Sec. 40-40. - Repairs to be made by city. 
    All sidewalk repairs shall be made by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-26) 
Sec. 40-41. - Sidewalk repairs to be set up prior to adoption of annual budget; inclusion of costs in budget. 
    Any program of sidewalk repair shall be set up in advance of the adoption of the annual city budget and the city's share of the cost shall be included in the budget. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-27) 
Sec. 40-42. - Manner of billing and assessing for sidewalk construction. 
    The cost of constructing sidewalks which are ordered by resolution of the city council or upon the written request of the property owner shall be billed and assessed as follows: 
(1)	The total estimated cost and expense of the work, as determined by the city council, shall be charged to the owner whose property abuts the sidewalk. 
(2)	If the owner fails to pay the cost and expense of the sidewalk construction within 30 days from the date of invoice, the city council shall cause the amount unpaid, together with a penalty of six percent to be reported to the city assessor, to be levied by the city assessor as a special tax or assessment upon the lot or premises adjacent to and abutting upon the sidewalk. 
(3)	The special assessment levied pursuant to subsection (2) of this section shall be subject to review, after proper notice is given as in all other cases of special assessments, and such tax, when confirmed, shall be a lien upon such lot or premises, the same as other special assessments, and shall be spread, together with such penalty upon the tax roll as a special assessment upon such lot or premises. 
(4)	Special assessments made pursuant to this section shall be collected in the same manner as other city taxes; or the city may collect such amount, together with the penalty from the owner of such premises in an action in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(5)	Whenever a majority of the members of the city council present and voting shall determine by resolution that the public necessity and welfare require a variation of this section, it may, in the same resolution, determine that the city shall bear up to 100 percent of the cost of such construction, and the cost to the abutting property owners shall abate accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 1968-1, § 1; Code 1972, § 14-28) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearing notice, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Sec. 40-43. - Manner of billing and assessing for sidewalk repairs. 
    The cost of repairing sidewalks which are ordered by resolution of the city council or upon written request of the property owner shall be billed and assessed as follows: 
(1)	The property owner's share of the costs shall be charged to the property owner. If the owner fails to pay the costs within 30 days from the date of the invoice, the city council shall cause the amount unpaid, together with a penalty of ten percent to be reported to the city assessor, to be levied by the city assessor as a special tax or assessment upon the lot or premises adjacent to and abutting upon such sidewalk, which special assessment shall be subject to review, after proper notice is given as in all other cases of special taxes or assessments, and when confirmed, shall be a lien upon such lot or premises, the same as other special assessments. 
(2)	Special taxes and assessments made pursuant to this section shall be spread, together with any penalty, upon the tax roll as a special assessment upon such lot or premises, and the special taxes and assessments shall be collected in the same manner as other city taxes or the city may collect such amount, together with the penalty as provided in subsection (1) of this section, from the owner of such premises in an action in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-29) 
State Law reference- Special assessment notices and hearing notice, MCL 211.741 et seq. 
Secs. 40-44-40-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK CONTRACTORS 

Sec. 40-71. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of constructing sidewalks in the city without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-40) 
Sec. 40-72. - Application for license; contents. 
    Application for a license required by this article shall be made to the city clerk and shall contain the name and place of business of the applicant, shall state that the applicant is qualified by experience to engage in the work of constructing sidewalks and is willing to be governed in all respects by the provisions of this Code and the resolution of the city council relating to sidewalk construction. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-41) 
Sec. 40-73. - License fee. 
    The fee for a license required by this article shall be as adopted by resolution of the city council from time to time and a copy of such resolution shall always be available in the offices of the city clerk and treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Ord. No. 1981-5, § 2; Code 1972, § 14-42) 
Sec. 40-74. - Insurance required; terms of policy. 
    Each licensed sidewalk contractor shall maintain, during the term of the license, such public liability and property damage insurance as shall protect the licensed sidewalk contractor and the city from claims for damage for personal injury, including wrongful death, as well as from claims for property damage which may arise from the contractor's operations as a sidewalk contractor within the city. The insurance policy shall name the city as an additional insured. The amounts of the insurance shall be as established by resolution of the city council from time to time. Certificates of public liability and property damage insurance shall be filed with the city clerk before the required license is granted. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-43) 
Sec. 40-75. - Duty to notify city clerk of address and name changes. 
    Each person licensed pursuant to this article shall notify the city clerk of any change in the licensed person's business address, residence address and name under which the business is transacted. 
(Ord. No. 1953-19; Code 1972, § 14-44) 
Chapter 42 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Budget procedure, general finance and taxation, § 7.1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-9(2); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes saved from repeal, § 1-9(7); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-9(10); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-141 et seq.; businesses, ch. 8. 
State Law reference- General property tax law, MCL 211.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Administration fee for collection of property taxes. 
    Whenever the city shall act as collecting agent for property taxes, there shall be added to such taxes, assessments and charges a property tax administration fee of not more than one percent of the total tax bill per parcel, which amount shall be calculated to the nearest $0.01 if a fraction shall result. A property tax administration fee is defined as a fee to offset costs incurred by the city in assessing property value-at one-half percent on the summer and one-half percent on the winter rolls, in collecting the property tax levies, and in review and appeal processes. Such administration fee shall not inure to the benefit of the city treasurer but shall be the property of the city and shall be deposited in the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 1969-4, § 4; Code 1972, § 2-41; Ord. No. 4-2005, § 1, 6-20-2005) 
Sec. 42-2. - Penalties for late payment of city taxes. 
    To all city taxes, and to all special assessments and charges appearing on the tax rolls of the city, which are paid during the months of September, October, November and December next following the first date on which such taxes, special assessments, and charges are due for payment, there shall also be added a penalty in the amount of one percent on all such payments made in the month of September, two percent in the month of October, three percent in the month of November, and four percent in the months of December, January and February. 
(Ord. No. 1953-12, § 3; Code 1972, § 2-42) 
Sec. 42-3. - Powers and duties of city treasurer. 
    In the collection of city taxes, the city treasurer shall do and perform all acts required by the city Charter for the collection of taxes and shall have and exercise all the powers granted by state law and the city Charter for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1953-12, § 4; Code 1972, § 2-43) 
State Law reference- Collection of taxes, MCL 211.44 et seq. 
Sec. 42-4. - Notice to property owners when taxes are delinquent; contents of notice. 
    During the first week of February of each year, the city treasurer shall give notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city that taxes, special assessments and charges are due and of the fact that all such taxes, assessments and charges which are not paid during the month of February will be returned to the county treasurer for collection under the general laws of the state. Such notice shall further advise that as to each delinquent taxpayer that the county treasurer will add a collection fee to the total of the several taxes, assessments and charges returned to the treasurer plus interest and that, if not paid according to the law, the property upon which such taxes are levied will be sold at tax sale. 
(Ord. No. 1953-12, § 5; Ord. No. 1993-4, § 1; Code 1972, § 2-44) 
Secs. 42-5-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INCOME TAX 

Sec. 42-31. - Adoption of uniform ordinance. 
    The "Uniform City Income Tax Ordinance," as set forth in 1964 PA 284 (MCL 141.501 et seq.), is hereby adopted by reference in its entirety by the city as though fully set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1997-4, § 1, 8-4-1997; Code 1972, § 151/2-1) 
Sec. 42-32. - Alternate provisions. 
    In accordance with the authority vested in the city pursuant to 1969 PA 42 (MCL 141.701 et seq.), sections 60, 61 and 87 of such act (MCL 141.760, 141.761, 141.787), are hereby adopted by reference in their entirety by the city as if fully set forth in this section. Such sections shall be applicable and in force in place of and in lieu of sections 60, 61 and 87 of chapter 2 of 1964 PA 284 (MCL 141.501 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1997-4, § 2, 8-4-1997; Code 1972, § 151/2-2) 
Sec. 42-33. - Amendments to statutes. 
    Sections 31 and 62 of 1964 PA 284 (MCL 141.631, 141.662) are to be amended as follows: 
(1)	141.631 Personal exemptions; limitations. 
    Sec. 31.  (1) For tax years beginning 2009, an individual tax payer, in computing his or her taxable income, is allowed a deduction of $750.00 for each personal and dependency exemption under the rules for determining exemptions and dependents as provided by the Federal Internal Revenue Code. The taxpayer may claim his or her spouse and dependents as exemptions, but if the taxpayer and the spouse are both subject to the tax imposed by this chapter, the number of exemptions claimed by each of them, when added together, shall not exceed the total number of exemptions allowed under this chapter. 
    (2) For tax years beginning after 1988, an additional exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a taxpayer who is 65 years of age or older, or who is blind as defined in section 504 of the Income Tax Act of 1967, 1967 PA 281 (MCL 206.504), or if the taxpayer is both 65 years of age or older and blind, two additional exemptions are allowed under subsection (1). For tax years beginning after 1988, an additional exemption is allowed under subsection (1) for a taxpayer who is a paraplegic, quadriplegic, hemiplegic or a totally and permanently disabled person, as defined in section 216 of title II of the Social Security Act, 42 USC 416, or a taxpayer who is a deaf person, as defined in section 2 of the Deaf Persons' Interpreters Act, 1982 PA 204 (MCL 393.502). If the taxpayer qualifies for an additional exemption under more than one of the following, an additional exemption is allowed for each of the following for which the taxpayer qualifies: 
(a)	A taxpayer who is a paraplegic, quadriplegic or hemiplegic, or who is a totally or permanently disabled person, as defined in section 216 of title II of the Social Security Act, 42 USC 416. 
(b)	A taxpayer who is blind, as defined in section 504 of the Income Tax Act of 1967, 1967 PA 281 (MCL 206.504). 
(c)	A taxpayer who is a deaf person, as defined in section 2 of the Deaf Persons' Interpreters Act, 1982 PA 204 (MCL 393.502). 
(d)	A taxpayer who is 65 years of age or older. 
    (3) For tax years beginning 2009, an exemption in the amount of $750.00 is allowed to a person with respect to whom a deduction under Section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code is allowable to another federal taxpayer during the tax year and who is, therefore, not considered to have a federal personal exemption under subsection (1). 
(2)	141.662 Declaration of estimated tax not withheld; filing. 
    Sec. 62.  (1) A person who anticipates taxable income from which the city income tax will not be withheld shall file a declaration of estimated tax on a form furnished by or obtainable on request from the city. A calendar year taxpayer shall file a declaration on or before April 30. A taxpayer on a fiscal-year basis or other accounting period shall file a declaration within four months after the beginning of each fiscal year or other accounting period. 
    (2) If a taxpayer has not previously been required to file, the declaration shall be filed on or before the first date for making a quarterly payment that occurs after the taxpayer becomes subject to the requirement to file a declaration. A taxpayer shall file a declaration for the same calendar year, fiscal year or other accounting period that has been accepted by the Federal Internal Revenue Service for federal income tax purposes. A declaration by an individual or unincorporated entity is not required if the total estimated tax, less any credits applicable to the tax, does not exceed $100.00. A declaration by a corporation if the total estimated tax, less any credits applicable to the tax, does not exceed $250.00. A declaration by or on behalf of an estate or trust is not required. 
(Ord. No. 1998-10, § 2; Ord. No. 1991-1, § 2(A), (B); Code 1972, § 151/2-3; Ord. No. 2009-2, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-2009) 
Chapter 44 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
