(Code 1972, § 18-68) 
Sec. 48-109. - Publication that unpaid charges shall be lien on premises and will be placed on tax roll for collection. 
    The city council shall thereupon order the publication, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and published at least weekly, of general notice to all owners of property within the city that all unpaid water rates, fees or charges which have remained unpaid for a period of three months or more as of March 1 which have not been paid by May 20 are a lien upon the property to which the water had been furnished and will be transferred to the tax roll and assessed upon the city tax roll against the property to which the water for which the unpaid rates, fees or charges accrued, to be collected in the same manner as city taxes on the tax roll. If the charges shall remain delinquent and unpaid after the expiration of the time limited in the warrant for the collection of taxes levied in such roll, such charges shall be returned to the county treasurer to be collected in the same manner as the lien created by taxes on the delinquent tax roll of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-69) 
Sec. 48-110. - Penalties and sanctions. 
    A person who violates any provision of sections 48-99 or 48-100 is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00 or more than $500.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction as provided in section 1-56. 
(Ord. No. 1997-5, § 9, 12-1-1997; Code 1972, § 18-70) 
Secs. 48-111-48-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - USE OF FIRE HYDRANT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 20. 

Sec. 48-126. - Permit required. 
    No person, except members of the public safety department, or the water superintendent or the superintendent's agent or representative, shall unlock, unscrew or take off the cap or cover of any fire hydrant, or open or close the valve thereof, or in any manner operate or use, or attempt to operate or use, any hydrant, except under a special written permission issued by the water superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-75) 
Sec. 48-127. - Permit to be for specific use. 
    Permits to use fire hydrants shall be granted by the water superintendent only for specific hydrants at specific times and for specific work. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-76) 
Sec. 48-128. - Display of permit upon request. 
    Any person issued a permit pursuant to this division shall keep the permit at the place of use and it shall be displayed to any member of the public safety department or city official upon request. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-77) 
Sec. 48-129. - Deposit required; use of deposit for damaged equipment. 
(a)	Any person desiring services from a fire hydrant shall place on deposit such a sum of money with the city clerk as shall be designated by the water superintendent in accordance with an appropriate resolution of the city council, which sum shall be held until all charges incurred have been fully paid and all city equipment returned in good condition. 
(b)	The water superintendent shall have the right to use any portion or all of such deposited sum to repair or replace any equipment damaged through negligence of the person using the hydrant or by reason of its use thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-78) 
Sec. 48-130. - Use of hydrant. 
(a)	Before the use of water from a fire hydrant shall be allowed, the discharge port shall first be fitted with a valve, approved by the public safety department, under the direction of the water superintendent. The main valve of the hydrant must be fully opened at the beginning of work each day, and remain open until the stoppage of work at night. The water supply shall be regulated by the independent valve. The hydrant shall be operated only by a proper hydrant wrench which shall be obtained from the water superintendent. 
(b)	Water must not be allowed to run, except when used. No leaking hose, pipe or joints shall be permitted. All persons using hydrants shall immediately obey any instructions or orders that may be issued by the water superintendent to regulate the use of the hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-79) 
Sec. 48-131. - Authority of city to require meter at expense of user; rates. 
    If the use of water from a fire hydrant is to be continued over a number of days, the water superintendent may require a water meter to be applied to the connection made with the fire hydrant at the expense of the party using the fire hydrant. The party using the fire hydrant shall pay for all water by meter measurement at the stipulated rates. 
(Ord. No. 1955-1; Code 1972, § 18-80) 
Secs. 48-132-48-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Battle Creek Township referred to in this division is now in the City of Battle Creek. 

Sec. 48-151. - Acquisition of water supply system within city limits. 
    Under authority of 1947 PA 235 (MCL 123.331 et seq.), the city hereby acquires and takes possession of that portion of the water supply system of Battle Creek Township, Calhoun County, Michigan, lying within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-86) 
Sec. 48-152. - Date of acquisition of water supply system. 
    The date on which the acquisition and taking possession shall be effective and that part of the water supply system of Battle Creek Township, Calhoun County, Michigan, shall become the property of the city shall be April 1, 1954. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-87) 
Sec. 48-153. - Contract for operation of system by city or township permissible. 
    The city and the Township of Battle Creek may, at any time, either before or after April 1, 1954, enter into a contract providing for the operation of both that part of the water system which lies within the city and that part thereof which lies in the Township of Battle Creek as a single unit by either of them as agent for both. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 123.335. 
Sec. 48-154. - Use of water system funds while bonds outstanding. 
    There being outstanding revenue bonds issued for the acquisition, construction, extension and improvement of the township water supply system, as the same existed on November 16, 1953, the integrity and unit operation of the entire system, including that part thereof within the city and that part thereof within the Township of Battle Creek shall be preserved, and the segregation, safekeeping and disposition of its revenues, as provided by the bond ordinance adopted by the Township of Battle Creek, as such ordinance existed on December 1, 1953, shall be continued until all outstanding bonds of that issue assumed by the revenues of the entire system shall have been retired by payment, redemption, assumption or exchange, or provision made for their priority in accordance with sections 6 and 8 of 1947 PA 235 (MCL 123.336, 123.338), under authority of which this article is adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-90) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 123.336. 
Sec. 48-155. - Management and disposition of system funds. 
    During the time that the bonds in section 48-154 shall remain outstanding and so long as the system shall be operated as a single unit by a joint board or by the city or the Township of Battle Creek as agent for both, the operating board or agency shall provide for the payment of the necessary amounts into the operation and maintenance fund and into the bond and interest redemption fund for all the bonds in section 48-154 which are secured by the revenues of the entire system. The city and the Township of Battle Creek may provide by contract for the holding and management of other revenues or for their apportionment and deposit into separate bonds and interest redemption funds for bonds, severally issued or assumed and into separate depreciation, contingent and surplus funds. Unless otherwise provided by such contract, such revenues shall be divided and paid quarterly or more often into their respective treasuries and set apart by each into the appropriate funds. Unless otherwise provided by such contract, the city and the Township of Battle Creek shall have control of the construction of extensions and improvements to the system within its boundaries, and shall be entitled to its proportion of the contingent and surplus funds of the system for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-91) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 123.340. 
Sec. 48-156. - Division of revenues and liabilities. 
    Unless otherwise provided by contract, all revenues of the system which are subject to apportionment and all the outstanding indebtedness to be separately funded or assumed by the city and the Township of Battle Creek shall be divided in proportion to the net revenues received during the preceding fiscal year from service rendered by the system to property within the respective boundaries of the two units of government. Upon the final separation of the system into that lying within the city and that lying within the Township of Battle Creek, or as otherwise agreed between them, any cash assets and intangible property of or pertaining to the system shall be divided between the city and township in the same proportion as provided in this division for the revenues and outstanding indebtedness to be separately funded or assumed. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-92) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 123.341. 
Sec. 48-157. - Present bond ordinance of township to remain in effect; further revenue bonds. 
    So long as the present outstanding bonds of the water system remain outstanding, or the priority thereof is not provided, as required and permitted by this division and by law, the ordinance of the Township of Battle Creek providing for the issuance thereof shall apply to and remain in full force and effect concerning the security of such bonds and, except as in this division provided, the water supply system shall be subject to the provisions of 1933 PA 94 (MCL 141.101 et seq.), which are applicable thereto. Provided, that neither the city nor the Township of Battle Creek shall have the power or authority to make any part of such system lying within the boundaries of the other subject to any further revenue bonds, under any authority whatsoever, without the consent of the legislative body of the other. 
(Ord. No. 1954-6; Code 1972, § 18-93) 
Secs. 48-158-48-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PRIVATE WATER SUPPLIES 

Sec. 48-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private water supply means any water supply not defined as a public and semipublic water supply. 
    Public and semipublic water supply means any water supply offered to or available to the public or any water supply used on any premises in a manner where the use of a contaminated water supply might constitute a menace to public health. This definition shall not include municipal supplies for cities. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-99) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 48-177. - Location. 
    All wells, springs, water suction lines and other drinking water structures shall be located at least 50 feet from seepage pits, cesspools, privies, septic tanks, subsurface disposal systems, county drains and other sources of contamination. Buried or exposed sewers or pipes through which sewage may back up shall be located at least ten feet from any well or suction pipe. When such sewers or pipes are located within a ten-foot to 50-foot area, they shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe with watertight joints or equal. Such pipes, when exposed and accessible for inspection, may be allowed not closer than ten feet of the well, spring or water suction line. All wells shall be located so that possibility of flooding is reduced to a minimum. The area immediately adjacent to the well shall be mounded up so that the surface water shall be diverted away from the well. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-100) 
Sec. 48-178. - Casings. 
    The casings of tubular wells shall be at least standard weight iron pipe, watertight through its length, and the joints shall be threaded. The casing of all tubular wells shall extend at least one inch above the surface of the platform floor or pedestal. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-101) 
Sec. 48-179. - Hand pumps. 
    Hand pumps shall be designed to exclude all contamination and shall have a closed pump spout directed downward. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-102) 
Sec. 48-180. - Power pumps. 
    Power pumps shall be designed and so fastened to the casing as to exclude all contamination. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-103) 
Sec. 48-181. - Public and semipublic water supplies to comply with division; distance from contamination sources. 
    All public and semipublic water supplies shall be located, constructed and maintained in accordance with the regulations of this division except the distance from sources of contamination shall not be less than 75 feet. 
(Ord. No. 1959-1; Code 1972, § 18-104) 
Sec. 48-182. - Water meter required for premises connected to city sewer with private water supply. 
    Where a private water supply services premises connected to any city sewer, those premises must have a water meter for the purpose of measuring water flow and determining sewer charges. Water meters shall be furnished by the city as provided in section 48-95 and the water superintendent shall have the right of entry into any such premises at any reasonable time to install such meter and the further right of entry and access for maintenance and repair as provided in section 48-32. 
(Ord. No. 1975-8, § 1; Code 1972, § 18-105) 
Secs. 48-183-48-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CROSS CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 48-201. - State department of environmental quality rules adopted by reference. 
    The city adopts by reference the Water Supply Cross Connection Rules of the state department of environmental quality, being R 325.11401 to R 325.11407 of the Michigan Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-106) 
Sec. 48-202. - Backflow inspections and testing. 
    It shall be the duty of the city water department to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the city water department and as approved by the state department of environmental quality. 
    All testable backflow prevention assemblies shall be tested initially upon installation to ensure proper working order. Subsequent testing of assemblies shall take place on an annual basis as required by the City of Springfield and in accordance with Michigan Department of Environmental Quality requirements. Only individuals that are approved by the City of Springfield and certified by the State of Michigan shall be qualified to perform such testing. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-107; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 1, 12-17-07) 
Sec. 48-203. - City's right of entry. 
    The representative of the city water department shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping systems thereof for cross connections. On request, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping systems on such property. The refusal of such information or refusal of access, when requested, shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-108) 
Sec. 48-204. - Discontinuance of water service where connection in violation of division exists. 
    The city water department is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service after reasonable notice to any property wherein any connection in violation of this division exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply system. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connection has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-109) 
Sec. 48-205. - Protection of potable water supply; labeling. 
    The potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this division and by the state and the city plumbing code. Any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as: 
WATER UNSAFE FOR DRINKING 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-110) 
Sec. 48-206. - Validity of other codes and ordinances. 
    This division does not supersede the single state construction code and divisions 1 through 6 of this article, but is supplementary to them. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-111) 
Sec. 48-207. - Cross connection control program. 
    The water superintendent is hereby authorized and directed to establish and promulgate a "cross connection control program" within the city. Such program shall be promulgated by the water superintendent immediately after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived and copies shall be filed in the offices of the water superintendent and the city clerk and shall be available to the public upon request at all times. The program shall have this division attached and made a part of it. This section is mandatory and not directory. 
(Ord. No. 1978-4, § 2; Code 1972, § 18-113) 
Sec. 48-208. - Violations. 
    Any person or customer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this division or any written order of the City of Springfield, in pursuance thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 for each violation. Each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this act shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 12-17-07) 
Secs. 48-209-48-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 48-231-48-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATION AND USE 

Sec. 48-246. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. "COD" denotes chemical oxygen demand. 
    Building connection means the connection of the building drain to the building sewer. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer which begins five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Developer means any person constructing a private sewer system. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing food and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    ICR means industrial cost recovery. 
    Industrial user means any user identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as now or hereafter amended or supplemented under the following divisions: 
(1)	Division A-Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing 
(2)	Division B-Mining 
(3)	Division D-Manufacturing 
(4)	Division S-Transportation, Communications, Electric, Gas and Sanitary Services 
(5)	Division I-Services 
Any user discharging less than the equivalent of 25,000 gallons per day shall be exempt from industrial cost recovery provided its waste discharge does not contain pollutants which (i) are toxic or incompatible; (ii) interfere with treatment works processes; or (iii) may otherwise contaminate or reduce the utility of the sludge. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Inspector means an authorized agent of the director of public works observing the construction, alteration, tapping or repair of any public or building sewer or engaged in other work provided for in this division. 
    Local costs means those costs which are borne in their entirety by the city and include all expenses incurred up to the point of delivery to the regional system. 
    Meter means a device to measure the quantity of water or wastewater passing through it. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Operation and maintenance costs means all costs for labor, power, chemicals, materials and supplies, replacements, contractual services, billing and administration chargeable to wastewater operations. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Plumber means a plumber who is licensed and authorized to engage in plumbing work in the city in accordance with city ordinances and state statutes. 
    Plumbing contractor means any contractor registered with the city to engage in work of a plumber. 
    Premises means a structure which cannot be completely divided in its present utilitarian condition through sale. The following are examples of what is meant by premises: 
(1)	A building under one roof owned, leased or occupied by one party as one business or residence; 
(2)	A combination of residential buildings or commercial buildings leased or occupied by one party in one common enclosure; 
(3)	The one side of a double house having a solid vertical partition wall; or 
(4)	A building owned by one party having more than one internal division, such as apartments, offices, stores, etc., and which may have a common or separate entrance. 
    Private sanitary sewer facilities means any privately owned and maintained privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or outlet into any pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
    Properly shredded garbage means wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights and is controlled by a public authority. 
    Residential user means any user introducing into the sewer system domestic strength wastes from premises used for family living. 
    Sanitary sewage means any sewage carried by a sanitary sewer system. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface water and groundwater are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent, or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed storm sewer) means a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Waste means any discarded or abandoned materials, whether organic or inorganic. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, §§ 18-115, 18-131) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 48-247. - Use of public sewer required. 
(a)	The use of public sewers shall be required within the city in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to discharge into any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this division. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste as may from time to time be specified by the director of public works. 
(d)	Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank or cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(e)	The owner of any structure within the city and in which structure water is used or is available for use for household, commercial, industrial or other purposes shall connect the structure at the earliest of the following dates or events to a sanitary sewer system located in a right-of-way, easement, highway, street or public way which crosses, adjoins or abuts the property and passing not more than 200 feet at the nearest point from the structure: 
(1)	Upon failure of the owner's current private sanitary sewer facilities; 
(2)	Upon sale of a structure in which sanitary sewage originates. For purposes of this section, the term "structure in which sanitary sewage originates" means a building in which toilet, kitchen, laundry, bathing or other facilities which generate water-carried sanitary sewage are used or are available for use for household, commercial, industrial or other purposes; 
(3)	Upon improvement of the property so as to become property upon or from which sanitary sewage originates. Connection to the public sanitary sewer system shall be made prior to occupancy; 
(4)	By December 31, 2004. 
(f)	At such time as any premises are connected to the public sewer, the owner shall complete the following: 
(1)	At the time that connection to the public sewer is completed, all connections to any private sanitary sewer facilities shall be disconnected. 
(2)	All cesspools, septic tanks, privy vaults, dry wells, block trenches and any other private sanitary sewer facilities shall be treated in compliance with requirements of the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-116) 
Sec. 48-248. - Use of private sanitary sewer facilities. 
(a)	The construction, installation, maintenance or use of private sanitary sewer facilities in the city shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(b)	Where a public sewer is not available as specified in section 48-247, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sanitary sewer facility as approved by the county health department or a successor agency having the same authority. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-117) 
Sec. 48-249. - Connection to public sewers. 
(a)	All sewer construction, installation, connections, maintenance and repairs shall be in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)	No person, except an authorized employee of the city or persons authorized by the city, shall uncover, make any connections with or into, install, repair, alter or disturb any public sewer, building sewer or appurtenance thereof. A written permit for such work issued by the director of public works shall be required for each interference with any public sewer or appurtenance thereto. 
(c)	Application for a permit required in subsection (b) of this section shall be signed by the owner of the property for which the connection is desired, or by the property owner's duly authorized agent, and must state the name and address of the owner, description of the property and state the purpose for which the connection is desired and shall designate the person to perform the work. The person designated to perform the work shall meet the qualifications for performing such work as may be required by the director of public works. There shall be written proof of the authorized agent's authority. Such application shall be on such form as specified by the director of public works and shall contain such further information as may be required by the director of public works. 
(d)	No permit shall be issued until all charges and fees, inclusive but not limited to connection charges, tap fees and other charges required by this division and any other ordinance of the city have been paid or provisions for the payment of the charges and fees have been made with the director of public works. 
(e)	All private plumbing costs and expenses related to and incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer to the public sewer, including the cost of materials and metering devices as may be required, shall be borne by and at the sole expense of the owner; provided, however, that the city council may by resolution and upon application by the owner agree to contract on the owner's behalf to pay such costs and expenses and thereafter permit the repayment of such costs and expenses to be made in installments over a five-year period with interest not to exceed nine percent per annum from the date of connection. It being further provided, however, that any delinquent payments shall be collectible in the manner provided in section 48-273(d). The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly result from the installation of the building sewer or connection to the public sewer. 
(f)	A separate and independent building sewer shall be required for each premises to be connected to the public sewer. 
(g)	All sewer construction, connections, maintenance and repairs to sewer facilities shall be subject to rules and regulations promulgated from time to time in accordance with the provisions of section 48-252 and shall conform to the building and plumbing codes of the city and any other applicable codes. 
(h)	Old building sewers may be used in connection with new premises only when they are found, on examination and test by the director of public works, to meet all requirements of this division. 
(i)	Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an apparatus approved by the director of public works and discharged to the building sewer. 
(j)	No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(1)	Whenever such connections are found in any premises, the director of public works shall notify the owner in writing in accordance with provisions for giving notice of any violations. 
(2)	Such connection shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance per se. 
(3)	Failure to remove such connection within 30 days from the date of service of notice shall be deemed to be a separate violation of this section. 
(k)	The person designated pursuant to subsection (c) of this section to perform the work of connecting, installing, repairing, altering or disturbing any public sewer shall notify the director of public works in writing at least 48 hours in advance when the building sewer will be ready for installation and connection to the public sewer. It is the responsibility of the person designated to do such work to ensure the delivery of such notice to the director of public works. This notice shall state the permit number, street, sublot number and anticipated construction time required for the inspection requested. The person designated to do the work shall immediately inform the director of public works of any unforseen delays or postponements prior to 8:00 a.m. of the day for which inspection was arranged. No work may be performed in the absence of an inspector unless written permission is granted by the director of public works. Such written permission shall not be unreasonably denied. The city shall not be liable for any expense incurred by the person designated to do the work in locating mains, wyes, house connections or other sewer appurtenances arising out of information procured from the records of the city. 
(l)	Any work covered previous to the inspection shall be uncovered by the person designated to do the work and an opportunity must be given to inspect the inside as well as the outside of the sewer pipe. The actual tapping of a connection into a sanitary sewer and the connection to the building drain shall be done only in the presence of an inspector. 
(m)	The director of public works shall approve the quality of all materials and workmanship and shall have the right to inspect the material and workmanship at all times. The director of public works may order removed from the job any inferior or defective material and the director of public works may cause to be relaid any portion of a building sewer which is not constructed in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(n)	Where a new sanitary sewer main is being built in a street and building drain or building sewer connections are included in the contract, the contractor for such sanitary sewer main shall be required to obtain a permit for each and every connection to a building drain that contractor may be employed to connect. 
(o)	No permit for sewer construction, connection, maintenance or repair shall be issued for any such work requiring excavation in any street, highway or road right-of-way until the person who is to make such excavation shall obtain from the proper authority the required permit for each excavation and shall agree to comply with all the requirements of the issuing authority, or shall obtain a written statement by that authority that no road opening permit is required. This permit shall be shown to the inspector at the commencement of the construction and shall be kept "on-the-job" at all times while work is in progress. 
(p)	No sanitary sewer connection will be made to any premises for which the rough interior plumbing has not been completed, inspected and approved by the proper authority. The connection between the interior plumbing, building drain and the sanitary sewer service connection (building sewer) shall be made at a point approximately five feet outside the inner face of the foundation wall. 
(q)	The property owner shall be responsible for the maintenance of the building sewer from the sanitary sewer main. The director of public works may require the property owner to make whatever repairs or perform any maintenance of the building sewer the director of public works deems necessary for the proper functions of the sanitary sewer system. If the city is requested or finds it necessary for the proper maintenance of the system to repair or maintain any building sewer or connections, the cost of such repair or maintenance shall be billed directly to the owner of the premises and shall be the responsibility of the owner to pay within 30 days from the date of the billing statement. Failure to pay such billed costs within six months of billing shall result in a lien being placed against the property in the amount of the cost, pursuant to provisions of other city ordinances. 
(r)	If any plumbing contractor shall neglect or refuse to do any act required by this division or the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder within the time specified after receiving written notice from the director of public works to do so, the director of public works may cause such work to be done and charge such work to the plumbing contractor. If such charges are not paid within 30 days from the date of the billing statement, the city council may revoke the plumbing contractor's authority to perform work in the city. Failure by the plumbing contractor to comply with the provisions of this division or the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder or with direct orders of the director of public works shall be deemed just cause for the city to revoke the plumbing contractor's authority to perform work in the city. This sanction shall be in addition to and not in lieu of those penalties provided for violation of this division. 
(s)	The city expressly disclaims and shall not be responsible for any damages caused by, or arising from any stoppage of the main sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-118) 
Sec. 48-250. - Use of the public sewers regulated. 
(a)	The use of the public sewers in the city shall be subject to the provisions of this section. Violation of the provisions of this section shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance per se. 
(b)	No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(c)	Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers, or to natural outlets approved by the appropriate state agency. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, upon approval of the appropriate state agency, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(d)	Except as provided by specific limits, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the wastes or waters to any public sewers prohibited by the standards of the City of Battle Creek. 
(e)	(1)	If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics referenced in subsection (d) of this section, and which in the judgment of the director of public works may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, process equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director of public works may: 
a.	Reject the wastes. 
b.	Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers. 
c.	Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge. 
d.	Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(2)	If the director of public works permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the director of public works and subject to all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(f)	Any person whose operations, residential or industrial, entail the discharge of water or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances shall file with the director of public works a written statement setting forth the nature of the operation contemplated or presently carried on, the amount of water required to be used and its source, the proposed point of discharge of such wastes into the sewage system of the city, the estimated amount to be discharged, and a fair statement setting forth the expected bacterial, physical, chemical and other known characteristics of such wastes. Within 30 days of receipt of such statement, it shall be the duty of the director of public works to make an order stating such minimum restrictions as in the judgment of the director of public works may be necessary to guard adequately against unlawful uses of the city's sewage system. 
(g)	Interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director of public works, they are necessary for the proper handling of the liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients such as ashes, cinders, sand, mud, etc. 
(h)	The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the director of public works. 
(i)	When required by the director of public works, the owner of any premises serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial or food establishment wastes shall install a suitable manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with a plan approved by the director of public works. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at the owner's expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(j)	All measurements, tests, and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples at such control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. 
(k)	All measurements, tests and analysis of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards of life, limb and property. 
(l)	Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any water or wastes, such facilities shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at the owner's expense. 
(m)	No statement contained in this section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength which may be determined to be detrimental to the public sewer system, or of toxic proportions or character, may be accepted by the city for treatment subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-119) 
Sec. 48-251. - Protection from damage. 
(a)	The sanitary sewer system shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(b)	Appeals. No person shall maliciously, willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Only authorized personnel shall be permitted to alter, uncover or tamper with any structure which is part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be deemed to be a disorderly person and shall be subject to criminal prosecution as provided in this division. Violation of this subsection shall be deemed to constitute a nuisance per se. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-120) 
Sec. 48-252. - Powers of the director of public works. 
(a)	The director of public works shall have the powers set out in this section. 
(b)	The director of public works is authorized and directed to adopt and enforce rules and regulations in accordance with the provisions of sections 48-247 through 48-250 for the purpose of providing control over sewer construction, installation, maintenance, repair and connections and the inspection thereof. Any rules and regulations promulgated by the director of public works shall be in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)	All such rules and regulations shall be entitled "Sanitary Sewer Rules and Regulations." 
(2)	All such rules and regulations and any amendments thereto shall be in writing and shall be filed with the clerk of the city and shall be placed on file at the office of the director of public works. 
(3)	Such rules and regulations shall specify the effective date thereof and shall be subscribed by the director of public works and dated as of the date they are promulgated. 
(c)	The director of public works shall maintain accurate and complete records of all public sewers and appurtenances, of all permits issued and all inspections made. The director of public works is empowered to require the abandonment and removal of all connections to the public storm sewers which violate the provisions of this division. 
(d)	The operation, maintenance, alterations, repair and management of the sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer system of the city shall be under the supervision and control of the city council, subject to the terms of the contract dated March 20, 1978, between the county and the city. The city council shall authorize the director of public works to employ such persons in such capacities as the director of public works deems advisable to carry on the efficient management and operation of the sanitary sewer system. The city council and director of public works may make such rules, orders and regulations as they deem advisable and necessary to ensure the efficient management and operation of the sanitary sewer system. 
(e)	The director of public works and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties and buildings, public and private, for the purpose of inspection, measurement, sampling and testing for violations of this division and the rules and regulations. However, the director of public works or the director's representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-121) 
Sec. 48-253. - Sewer line extension. 
(a)	Sewer lines shall be extended in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)	The developer of any new subdivision, or parts thereof, shall install all sewer mains, manholes, wyes and other appurtenances at the developer's own expense. Only standard manhole rings and covers used by the city will be approved. All work performed shall be in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the director of public works. 
(c)	Line extensions in previously established subdivisions having no sewer service, but petitioned for by the adjoining lot owners, will be installed on an assessment basis. No extension of sewer mains will be approved for less than the entire frontage of the subdivision or property found in the application, or applicant's property and the necessary length from the existing main to that frontage. 
(d)	The city council may extend sewer lines in areas where application or petition has not been received if the city council finds such extension is in the best interest of the general public health and welfare, or it is necessary to pass such properties to reach an area where application or petition has been made. In such cases, the council shall charge any benefited property for local service. 
(e)	No public sewer shall be constructed in the city except by the city or by others in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the director of public works, and subject to inspection by the director of public works during construction. No sewer shall be considered to be a part of the sewage system until accepted in writing by the director of public works. 
(f)	The size, slope, alignment, material of construction, method to be used in excavating, placing of pipe, jointing, testing, backfilling any sewer, and any other work connected with the construction shall conform to the requirements of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-122) 
Sec. 48-254. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any person violating any provision of this division shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stalled in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)	Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided in subsection (a) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)	Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1979-4, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-123) 
Secs. 48-255-48-271. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 48-272. - Sewer charges and rates generally. 
(a)	Each premises required to pay use charge. Each premises abutting a public gravity sanitary sewer line within the city which is required to connect to the sanitary sewer line by the provisions of subsection 48-247(e) shall pay a use charge based on the following rates. Such use charge shall commence as of the date such premises are connected to the public sanitary sewer system. 
(b)	Basis for wastewater service charges. 
(1)	The wastewater service charge for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater facilities of the city shall consist of a basic user charge for operation and maintenance plus replacement, a debt service charge and a surcharge, if applicable. 
(2)	The debt service charge shall be computed by dividing the annual debt service of all outstanding loans by the number of users. Through further divisions, the monthly debt service charges can be computed. 
(3)	The basic user charge shall be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for wastes having the following normal concentrations: 
a.	A five-day, 20-degree Celsius biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of 200 milligrams per liter (mg/1); 
b.	A suspended solids (SS) content of 250 mg/l. 
(4)	lt shall consist of operations and maintenance costs plus replacement and shall be computed as follows: 
a.	Estimate the projected annual revenue required to operate and maintain the wastewater facilities, including a replacement fund for the year, for all works categories; 
b.	Proportion the estimated costs to wastewater facility categories by volume, suspended solids and BOD, if possible; 
c.	Estimate wastewater volume, pounds of suspended solids and pounds of BOD to be treated; 
d.	Proportion the estimated cost to nonindustrial and industrial users by volume, suspended solids and BOD. 
e.	Compute costs per 100 cubic feet of metered water used for normal sewage strength. 
f.	Compute surcharge costs per pound in excess of normal sewage strength for BOD and suspended solids. 
(c)	Surcharge. A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed the normal concentrations for BOD (200 mg/l) and suspended solids (250 mg/l). The surcharge will be based on water usage as recorded by water meters and/or sewage meters for all wastes which exceed the 200 mg/l and 250 mg/l concentration for BOD and suspended solids, respectively. 
(d)	Review of charges. The adequacy of the wastewater charge shall be reviewed annually by certified public accountants for the city in the certified public accountants' annual audit report. The wastewater service charge shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in debt service or a change in operation and maintenance costs, including replacement costs, in accordance to applicable federal regulations. 
(e)	Industrial cost recovery. When an industrial user, as defined in 40 CFR 35.905-8, requests connection to the public sewage collection and disposal system, an industrial cost recovery system must be developed in accordance with 40 CFR 35.928. 
(f)	Premises not connected to the city water system . Each premises abutting a public gravity sanitary sewer line within the city which is required to connect to the sanitary sewer line by the provisions of subsection 48-247(e) but is not connected to the city water system shall be charged on the following basis: 
(1)	A flat rate which shall be set by the council to reflect average sewer usage; or 
(2)	A meter may be installed at the request of the owner, and at the owner's expense, on the private water supply. All installation, repairs, maintenance and other service costs shall be paid for by the owner. 
(g)	Installation of sewage meter. At the discretion of the owner of the premises and at the owner's cost, a sewage meter may be installed in the sewer line of such premises which shall be used to establish the use charges and any other applicable rates. The meter shall be of the type approved by the director of public works. All installation, repairs, maintenance and other service costs shall be paid for by the owner. During periods when the meter is deemed inaccurate or is out of service, the rate structure shall revert to previous averages based on city records or on the basis of metered water. 
(h)	Free service. No free service shall be furnished by the sanitary sewer system to any person, firm or corporation, public or private, or to any public agency or instrumentality. 
(i)	Effective date of charges and rates. The charges and rates established in this division shall be applied to each account commencing at the next full billing period following the effective date of this division. Any changes in charges and rates pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be applied to each account commencing at the next full billing period following the effective date of the change. 
(j)	Billing. 
(1)	Meters of all residential premises shall be read bimonthly and meters of all other premises shall be read monthly. Billings shall be rendered bimonthly for all residential premises and shall be rendered monthly for all other premises. Bills shall be due and payable at the office of the city treasurer not later than the day established by the council. Payments received after that day shall bear a service charge of ten percent of the amount of the bill. 
(2)	Sewer maintenance charges shall be billed in conjunction with and collected at the same time and in the same manner as water consumption charges. 
(Ord. No. 1979-5, § 3; Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-132) 
Sec. 48-273. - Other fees and charges. 
(a)	Roadway cutting fee and permits. When a connection is required to a sanitary sewer located within the public right-of-way where no service lateral has been installed to the property line, there shall be a street cutting permit obtained from the director of public works. At the time such permit is obtained, a fee shall be collected, such fee to cover the cost of restoring the street to its original condition. The permit shall be obtained and fee paid at the time application is made for such connection, with all fees being deposited in the street fund of the city. It shall be the responsibility of the plumbing contractor to install the lateral in accordance with the provisions of division 2 of this article. 
(b)	Connection fee. When a property owner has been assessed for a portion of the cost of laying a sanitary sewer main and where a lateral has been placed from the main to the property line but no assessment has been levied for the cost of placing such lateral, a connection fee of $600.00 shall be charged to the property owner in lieu of the assessment. This charge is due and payable at the time application is made for connection to the sanitary sewer system, such monies to be deposited in the sewer system fund of the city, provided, however, that for connections made on or before December 31, 2004, the connection fee referred to in this section may be paid in installments in the same manner as provided in subsection (c)(2) of this section for fees in lieu of special assessment. 
(c)	Fee in lieu of special assessment. Those properties which have not been assessed for the laying of a sanitary sewer main in abutting streets shall be charged a fee in lieu of the special assessment per the following conditions: 
(1)	Those mains laid under special assessment 16-S shall be charged $3.28 per front foot of property, such fee due and payable at the time application is made to connect to the sanitary sewer system. Such money shall be deposited in the sanitary sewer fund of the city. 
(2)	Those mains laid under Western Calhoun County System 2-A (City of Springfield) under the terms of the contract with the county dated March 20, 1978, shall be charged $1,200.00, such fee due and payable at the time application is made to connect to the sanitary sewer system. Such money shall be deposited in the sanitary sewer fund of the city. It is further provided that for connections made on or before December 31, 2004, any fee in lieu of special assessment imposed by the provisions of this section may be paid in installments in accordance with the following: 
a.	Application for installment payment may be made to the city treasurer; 
b.	The fee or charge may be made in quarterly payments over not more than a five-year period, bearing interest on the unpaid installments to accrue from the date of billing by the city. The rate of interest shall be equivalent to the rate that was applicable to the bonds issued by governmental authority for the construction of that portion of the system to which the tax is made, or nine percent per annum, whichever is greater; 
c.	Quarterly installment payments shall be due according to such schedule as may be determined by the city council by resolution. 
(d)	Lien rights. All delinquent rates, charges, installment payments and fees for sewer service or connection shall constitute a lien upon the premises served which shall be subject to foreclosure in the same manner as mechanic's liens for nonpayment, or after three months delinquency, may be certified to the city treasurer and assessing officer of the city annually, on or before March 1 of each year and entered by such assessing officer upon the next tax roll against the property served, for collection in the same manner as the collection of taxes. In addition, the city treasurer shall have the right to pursue a collection action against the owner of the premises and may enforce the delinquency as a debt owed to the city. In any action brought under this section, the city may recover, in addition to the amount of any delinquency due at that time, its actual expenses, including attorney fees, to which the city has been put in connection with the collection action up to the entry of judgment. 
(Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-133) 
Sec. 48-274. - Establishment of charges. 
(a)	Action by resolution. 
(1)	The use rates, special rates, and any fees and/or surcharges to be imposed by this division shall be in accordance with the respective schedule for such charges as established by the council of the city from time to time. Any changes of such charges shall be established pursuant to resolution of the city council. 
(2)	Owners of property within the city whose property now is connected with any public sewer, and property owners whose property may hereafter be connected with any public sewer, shall pay a charge therefor to be computed in accordance with a schedule of rates established by resolution of the city council. The city council may, by resolution, establish separate rates of charges for industrial establishments having a connection with city sewers, where such industrial establishment uses water for other than sanitary sewer purposes. Such rate, as determined by the city council, shall be in lieu of any sewer charge which might be charged under the regular schedule of rates. 
(b)	Publication. The initial schedules and any changes shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation within the city, and qualified under state law to publish legal notices. 
(c)	Effective date. The effective date of any changes shall not be less than 30 days after adoption by the city council, provided that publication shall be no less than ten days prior to the effective date of such changes. 
(Ord. No. 1979-5, § 3; Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-134) 
Sec. 48-275. - Fund and accounts of the system. 
(a)	Operating year. The sanitary sewer system shall be operated on the basis of an operating year commencing on July 1 and ending on June 30 of the following year. 
(b)	Monies. The treasurer of the city shall be custodian of all monies of the city belonging to, or associated with, this system and such monies shall be deposited in any state bank duly designated by the council of the city which is insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
(c)	Funds and accounts. The revenues of the system shall be set aside, as collected, and deposited in a separate depository account in a local bank duly qualified to do business in the state, in an account to be designated sewer system receiving fund (hereinafter, for brevity, referred to as the "receiving fund") and such revenues so deposited shall be transferred from the receiving fund periodically in the manner and at the times hereafter specified. 
(1)	Operation and maintenance fund. Out of the revenues in the receiving fund, there shall be first set aside quarterly into a depository account, designated operation and maintenance fund, a sum sufficient to provide for the payment of the next quarter's current expenses of administration and operation of the system and such current expenses for the maintenance thereof as may be necessary to preserve the system in good repair and working order. 
(2)	Contract payment fund. There shall next be established and maintained a depository account to be designated contract payment fund, which shall be used solely for the payment of the city's obligations to the county pursuant to the contract. There shall be deposited in such fund quarterly, after requirements of the operation and maintenance fund have been met, such sums as shall be necessary to pay such contractual obligations that cannot be met by the 1978.1 sanitary sewer special assessment fund. Should the revenues of the system and special assessment fund prove insufficient for this purpose, such revenues may be supplemented by any other funds of the city legally available for such purpose. 
(3)	Replacement fund. There shall next be established and maintained a depository account, designated replacement fund, which shall be used solely for the purpose of making major repairs and replacements to the system if needed. There shall be set aside into such fund, after provision has been made for the operation and maintenance fund and the contract payment fund, such revenues as the city council shall deem necessary for this purpose. 
(4)	Improvement fund. There shall next be established and maintained an improvement fund for the purpose of making improvement, extensions and enlargements to the system. There shall be deposited into such fund, after providing for such improvement fund, such revenues as the city council shall determine. 
(5)	Surplus moneys. Moneys remaining in the receiving fund at the end of any operating year, after full satisfaction of the requirements of the funds stated in subsections (c)(1)-(c)(4) of this section, may, at the option of the city council, be transferred to the improvement fund or used in connection with any other project of the city reasonably related to purposes of the system. 
(6)	Bank accounts. All moneys belonging to any of the funds stated in subsections (c)(1)-(c)(4) of this section or accounts may be kept in one bank account, in which event the moneys shall be allocated on the books and records of the city within this single bank account, in the manner set forth in this subsection (c)(6). 
If the moneys in the receiving funds are insufficient to provide for the current requirements of the operation and maintenance funds, any moneys and/or securities in other funds of the system, except sums in the contract payment fund derived from tax levies, shall be transferred to the operation and maintenance fund, to the extent of any deficit therein. 
(d)	Investment. Moneys in any fund or account established by the provisions of this division may be invested in obligations of the United States of America in the manner and subject to the limitations provided in 1933 PA 94 (MCL 141.101 et seq.). If such investments are made, the securities representing the investments shall be kept on deposit with the bank or trust company having on deposit the fund from which such purchase was made. Income received from such investments shall be credited to the fund from which such investments were made. 
(Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-135) 
Sec. 48-276. - Appeals. 
(a)	Hardship. The owner of any premises which have been assessed any charges under this division or any other ordinances with regard to the sewer system may submit a hardship application to the city seeking a deferment in the partial or total payments of the charges based upon a showing of financial hardship subject to and in accordance with the following: 
(1)	The owner of the premises shall complete a hardship application provided by the city council and file such application together with all other information and documentation reasonably required by the city, with the city council not less than 60 days prior to the date of the annual installment due. Any such deferment shall be for that annual installment only. An application shall be completed and filed by each and every legal and equitable interest holder in the premises so assessed, excepting financial institutions having security interest in the premises. 
(2)	Hardship applications shall be reviewed by the city council and after due deliberation of hardship applications, the city council shall determine in each case whether there has been an adequate showing of financial hardship and shall forthwith notify the applicant of such determination. 
(3)	An applicant aggrieved by the determination of the city council may request the opportunity to appear before the city council in person for the purpose of showing hardship and presenting any argument or additional evidence. Denial of hardship following such a personal appearance before the city council shall be final and conclusive. 
(4)	If the city council makes a finding of hardship, the council shall fix the amount of deferment of partial or total charges so imposed and in so doing shall require an annual filing of financial status by each applicant, provided that, upon any material change of the financial status of an applicant, such applicant shall immediately notify the assessor so that a further review of the matter may be made by the city council, and provided further that the duration of the deferment granted shall be self-terminating upon the occurrence of any one of the following events: 
a.	Change of the applicant's financial status which removes the basis for financial hardship; 
b.	Any conveyance of any interest in the premises by any of the applicants, including the execution of a new security interest in the premises or extension thereof; 
c.	A death of any of the applicants. 
(b)	Appeals. Any decision of the city sewer or water department which adversely affects any user of the city sanitary sewer system may be appealed to the city council following procedures established by the city council for such appeals. 
(Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-136) 
Sec. 48-277. - Enforcement and interpretation. 
(a)	Report of delinquent sewer charges. All unpaid sanitary sewer charges which, upon March 1 of each year, have remained unpaid for three months or more, shall be reported by the city clerk to the city council at the first meeting thereof in the month of March. 
(b)	Lien. The city council shall thereupon order the publication, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and published at least weekly, of general notice to all owners of property within the city that all unpaid sewer rates, fees or charges which have remained unpaid for a period of three months or more as of March 1 which have not been paid by May 20 are a lien upon the property to which the sewer service had been furnished and will be transferred to the tax roll and assessed upon the city tax roll against the property to which the sewer service for which the unpaid rates, fees or charges accrued, to be collected in the same manner as city taxes on the tax roll. If the fees and charges shall remain delinquent and unpaid after the expiration of the time limited in the warrant for the collection of taxes levied in such roll, such charges shall be returned to the county treasurer to be collected in the same manner as the lien created by taxes on the delinquent tax roll of the city. 
(c)	Shutoff of services. In addition to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, the city shall have the right to shut off sewer service to any premises for which charges for sewer service are more than three months delinquent, and such service shall not be reestablished until all delinquent charges and penalties and a turn-on charge to be specified by the city council have been paid. Further, such charges and penalties may be recovered by the city by court action. 
(Ord. No. 1979-6, § 3; Code 1972, § 18-137) 
Chapter 50 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Construction of language. 
    The following rules of construction apply to the text of this chapter: 
(1)	The particular shall control the general. 
(2)	ln the case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this chapter and any caption or illustration, the text shall control. 
(3)	The word "shall" is always mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may" is permissive. 
(4)	Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular number shall include the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. 
(5)	A "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof. 
(6)	The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for," "designed for," "intended for," "maintained for," or "occupied for." 
(7)	The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 
(8)	Unless the context clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or," or "either or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.	The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions, or events shall apply; 
b.	The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination; 
c.	The term "either...or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(9)	Terms not defined in this chapter shall have the meaning customarily assigned to them. 
(Ord. of 1-16-1978, § 200; Code 1972, app. A, § 200) 
Sec. 50-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory use and accessory mean a use which is clearly incidental to, customarily found in connection with and located on the same zoning lot, unless otherwise specified, as the principal use to which it is related. When the term "accessory" is used in this text, it shall have the same meaning as accessory use. An accessory use includes, but it not limited to, the following: 
(1)	Residential accommodations for servants and/or caretakers. 
(2)	Swimming pools for the use of the occupants of a residence, or such occupants guests. 
(3)	Domestic or agricultural storage in a barn, shed, toolroom or similar accessory building or other structure. 
(4)	A newsstand primarily for the convenience of the occupants of a building, which is located wholly within such building and has no exterior signs or displays. 
(5)	Storage of merchandise normally carried in stock in connection with a business or industrial use, unless such storage is excluded in the applicable district regulations. 
(6)	Storage of goods used in or produced by industrial uses or related activities, unless such storage is excluded in the applicable district. 
(7)	Accessory off-street parking spaces, open or enclosed, subject to the accessory off-street parking regulations for the district in which the zoning lot is located. 
(8)	Uses clearly incidental to a main use, such as, but not limited to, offices of an industrial or commercial complex located on the site of the commercial or industrial complex. 
(9)	Accessory off-street loading, subject to the off-street loading regulations for the district in which the zoning lot is located. 
(10)	Accessory signs, subject to the sign regulations for the district in which the zoning lot is located. 
    Alley means any dedicated public way affording a secondary means of access to abutting property and not intended for general traffic circulation. 
    Alterations means any change, addition or modification in construction of the type of occupancy or in the structural members of a building, such as walls or partitions, columns, beams or girders, the consummated act of which may be referred to as "altered or reconstructed." 
    Apartment means a suite of rooms or a room in a multiple-family building arranged and intended for a place of residence of a single-family or a group of individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit. 
    Automotive repair means the general repair, engine rebuilding, rebuilding or reconditioning of motor vehicles; collision service, such as body, frame or fender straightening and repair, overall painting and undercoating of automobiles. 
    Automotive storage, damaged, means any storage of inoperable vehicles not incidental to a service garage. 
    Automotive or trailer sales area means space used for the display, sale or rental of motor vehicles or trailers in new, used and operable condition. 
    Basement means the portion of a building which is partly or wholly below grade, but so located that the vertical distance from the average grade to the floor is greater than the vertical distance from the average grade to the ceiling. A basement shall not be counted as a story. 
    Block means the property abutting one side of a street and lying between the two nearest intersecting streets, (crossing or terminating) or between the nearest such street and railroad right-of-way, unsubdivided acreage, lake, river or live stream; or between any of such areas and any other barrier to the continuity of development, or corporate boundary lines of the city. 
    Board of appeals means a board consisting of five members, appointed by the city council, to hear and decide appeals and to provide interpretations in matters concerning the zoning ordinance of the city. 
    Building means a structure erected on site, a mobile home or mobile structure, a premanufactured or precut structure, above or below ground, designed primarily for the shelter, support or enclosure of persons, animals or property of any kind. 
    Building height means the vertical distance measured from the established grade to the highest point of the roof surface for flat roofs; to the deck line of mansard roofs; and to the average height between eaves and ridge for gable, hip and gambrel roofs. 
    Building line means a line formed by the face of the building, and for the purposes of this chapter, a minimum building line is the same as a front setback line. 
    Club means an organization of persons for special purposes or for the promulgation of sports, arts, sciences, literature, politics or the like, but not operated for profit. 
    Code official means the zoning administrator. 
    Condominium means the individual ownership of a unit or parcel of real property within a multi-unit parcel or structure, located as a permitted use within a zoning classification and requirements of this chapter. 
    Convalescent or nursing home means a structure with sleeping rooms, where persons are housed or lodged and are furnished with meals, nursing and limited medical care. 
    Development means the construction of a new building or other structure on a zoning lot, the relocation of an existing building on another zoning lot, or the use of open land for a new use. 
    District means a portion of the incorporated area of the city within which certain regulations and requirements or various combinations thereof apply under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Drive-in means a business establishment so developed that its retail or service character is dependent on providing a driveway approach or parking spaces for motor vehicles so as to serve patrons while in the motor vehicle rather than within a building or structure, or to provide self-service for patrons and food carryout. 
    Drive-in restaurant means a restaurant so developed that its retail or service character is primarily dependent on providing a driveway approach or parking spaces for motor vehicles so as to serve patrons while in the motor vehicle or to permit patrons to eat while in the motor vehicle, as well as within a building or structure, or primarily to provide self-service for patrons and food carryout. 
    Driveway, residential, means an area surfaced with concrete, asphalt, brick or gravel which leads from an authorized curb cut to required parking spaces or a garage or carport. A driveway shall have a minimum width of ten feet and a maximum width of 24 feet. Within a residential district, no parking area shall be used for parking or storing of any commercial vehicle exceeding a rated hauling capacity of one ton. 
    Dwelling, multiple-family, means a building containing three or more dwelling units designed for residential use and conforming in all respects to the standards set forth in the definition for "Dwelling, single-family." 
    Dwelling, one-family, means a building designed exclusively for and occupied exclusively by one family.
